movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: For true cinematic spectacle, Avatar is out of this world.
Kabali is the first of his films in a long time that shows off the superstar as a proper actor.
This remake of the 2013 South Korean film Montage is a suspenseful thriller with a trifecta of arguably the best dramatic actors in Bollywood leading the charge.
The breakout star here is an injured bird -- a seagull Nancy names Steven -- which stays with her throughout most of her ordeal and provides comic relief befitting a B-movie.
Rustom is just an ineffectual reimagining of meaty source material. Its cause is not helped by ominous-sounding background music that attempts to create tension throughout.
Ultimately, Roshan's sincerity carries the film, which would otherwise flounder in its own plot holes.

Thankfully, Padukone's Padmavati gets to be more than a pretty face in the second half of the film as she rallies the Rajput women in the lead-up to the stirring climax, which is masterfully handled by Bhansali.
All the apprehension and nostalgia in the music translates beautifully to the screen under Jonathan Demme's direction.
A riveting story well told.
A timeless movie, and offers a rare chance for the whole family to take a spectacular cinematic trip across continents and cultures.
movie_title: The Cave of the Yellow Dog (Die Hohle des gelben Hundes) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Binder has set a difficult bar -- to make a funny, sad, original movie about the healing power of not necessarily healing -- and he just manages to clear it.
Better to rent Scenes From a Marriage, Manhattan or My Dinner With Andre and stay home -- flannel pajamas optional.
The dour, downbeat story eventually spirals into grisly Grand Guignol and contrivance.
This would be as delightful and attractive a production without the gimcrackery.
Following up on his execrable 2005 semi-hit Are We There Yet?, Ice Cube once again turns the world off with a scowl in Are We Done Yet?
For all the posers with light sticks and piercings, there are moments of Dada-esque beauty, not to mention some great music from Tinariwen, Bjork, David Bowie and the late, great Joe Strummer.
Hot Fuzz could easily have lost 20 minutes or so in jittery montages and stylized set pieces. But for viewers in the mood for smart-stupid slapstick, it's a diverting jape.
There's an undeniable sweetness to the movie's celebration of surrendering to one's best self.
The TV Set, written and directed by Jake Kasdan, often possesses the gimlet-eyed wit of The Player or the mock docs of Christopher Guest.

In an apparent effort to put a stake in the heart of the franchise that threatens to define his career, director Sam Raimi has delivered an overlong, visually incoherent, mean-spirited and often just plain awful Spider-Man 3.
Mafioso may have been made in another era, but it stands as a classy, even radical rebuke to the film school posers who keep recycling the same tired gangster tropes.

With its tired reworking of Pygmalion and stiff, amateurish staging, Americanizing Shelley is clearly all about one thing: Gujral. She's cute, but by the end of this ego trip, she's more insufferable than adorable.
Rarely has love at any age been depicted so honestly on screen. For such a fully realized portrait to be created by a 28-year-old first-time director is even more remarkable.
[Director] Panahi has perfected the art of realist filmmaking, here turning his camera on scenes that seem more improvised or captured on the fly than staged.

Everyone in The Valet is likable; the movie even manages to be somewhat subversive, as it posits the idea that supermodels are people, too. Not to mention smart, kind and down-to-earth people. Quelle surprise!
Unfolds like an epistolary psychological mystery. Little about or in this movie is as simple as it seems.
Unfortunately, Provoked possesses the tinny production values and schmaltzy music of a prime-time special, despite its ensemble of terrific actors.
Even the uninitiated will be hard-pressed to resist the movie's charms, from its likable leading players and its charming Dublin setting to its wistful take on modern love.
Paris, je t'aime builds into something quite wonderful.
Never quite breaks out of its talky inertia.
If you've seen the ads, you've seen the movie.
A film all high school seniors should see. And their parents. And their siblings, neighbors, best friends and acquaintances. You should see it, too.
Killer of Sheep is unlike any other American film of its time or any other.
This drab exercise in glum piety slumps where it should soar, sapping the story of its mystery and transcendence with an overriding sense of literality.
This overproduced romantic comedy doesn't even qualify as fluff; it's flat, featureless plastic.
For its flaws, Blood Diamond is a gem, if only for being an unusually smart, engaged popcorn flick.
... a by turns poetic and hard-hitting critique of the global coffee industry ...
A nifty little psychological crime thriller that suggests a Treasure of the Sierra Madre for the postindustrial age.
It's a fun ride, and the big payoff -- that history turns out to be way cooler than its reputation suggests -- is even more gratifying.
An audacious, exhilarating futuristic thriller.
...An uneven success.
A slick piece of computer animation that can be described as a family film only in the sense that it's a film the whole family will want to avoid.
What starts as a taut urban crime drama quickly sags into lurid after-school-special sentimentality.

Aside from Cedric's admittedly appealing persona -- he's always watchable, even in dreck like this -- there's absolutely nothing to recommend The Cleaner, not the putative comedy nor the action, which kicks in only at the end.
[An] affecting and engaging film.
What the filmmakers try to play for laughs isn't funny, it's creepy.

So breathtaking in its artistic ambition, so technically accomplished, so morally expansive, so fully realized that it defies the usual critical blather. See it, and celebrate that rare occasion when a director has the audacity to commit cinema.

For all its contrivances (including Vera Farmiga's improbably erudite whore), Breaking and Entering has its finger on the pulse of contemporary London life and possesses its share of fleeting delights.

The beloved children's book has not just survived but thrived in its adaptation to the screen, its delicate combination of coming-of-age angst, tragedy and fantasy handled with assurance and taste by first-time live-action director Gabor Csupo.

This observant little movie does delicately touch on those unspoken assumptions that animate so many filial relationships. And the wry, soft-spoken tone is a welcome one amid the dysfunctional burlesques Hollywood routinely extrudes.
Nader haters may not be mollified, but An Unreasonable Man, like its subject itself, is a one-stop civics lesson no one should miss.

Brewer's reworking of Southern mythologies can sometimes seem condescending, even though his affection for the region's culture is palpable. But there's no denying he knows how to spin a yarn and create vivid, indelible images.
Director Michael O. Sajbel too often succumbs to movie-of-the-week sentimentality and starchy pacing.

It's worth watching as yet another example of Lynch's extraordinary collaboration with Dern. It may be overstating things to call her performance heroic, but it's nothing if not brave, as she dares to embody Lynch's most brutal impressions of Hollywood.
Knocked Up turns out to be not just rude, crude and outrageously funny but a deceptively sophisticated meditation on moral agency -- with pot jokes!
Everyone is given their due and dignity in this funny, sexy, humanist film that, if it is a chick flick, gives the genre a good name.
Day Watch may not suit everyone, but it opens a big can of Russian whoop-de-whoop on anyone willing to take it.
The Darjeeling Limited has its charms, chief of which is watching three terrific actors evince with unforced ease the rewards and resentments of brotherhood.

This uncommonly intelligent thriller evokes the great films of the 1970s (All the President's Men, Klute, Three Days of the Condor) that managed to elicit gritty urban realism while maintaining a suave sense of style and moral complexity.
As always, Phoenix is an arresting presence on screen, but don't expect any Departed-esque fast talk from Wahlberg, who is oddly inert in a role that should crackle with brotherly ambivalence.
As it goes about hitting its predictable marks, including a reassuring burst of moral outrage, Rendition suffers, finally, from not being extraordinary enough.
It should be required viewing before going into a supermarket, McDonald's or your very own refrigerator.
Gosling's performance is a small miracle, not only because he's so completely open as a man who's essentially shut off, but because he changes and grows so imperceptibly before our eyes.
The kind of sentimental, patently false romantic pandering whose idea of resolving a scene is for everyone to engage in some cute form of eccentric group activity.
As important for what it reveals about a seminal and grievously misunderstood artist as for how it rejuvenates a moribund documentary form.
Little more than a sleek, stylish stunt.
Ambitious, uneven and deeply affecting drama.

In addition to being a study in great acting, this is a study in great directing. Filming with high-definition digital video cameras, Lumet weaves in and out of the action, proving to be as adroit with new technology as he was with old-school celluloid.
movie_title: Before the Devil Knows You're Dead (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Radcliffe is good at showing vulnerability but without the skills to give it gradation. The magic doesn't work for him this time.

Provides context and an invaluable human face to a story that too many Westerners perceive as distant or irrelevant, if they perceive it at all. See Darfur Now, and you won't read the daily news the same way again.
For all its passion and topical currency, the movie plays too often like a college colloquium.
Lush, extravagant, sad and touching, Love in the Time of Cholera still feels weirdly insubstantial when all the febrile passion has abated. Like a fever it breaks, passes and is forgotten.
movie_title: Love in the Time of Cholera (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Price of Sugar is designed to educate, outrage and finally spur viewers to action. That it does so with vibrant visual style and an engaging narrative makes it that rare consciousness-raising film that's not only good for you, but a joy to watch.
This is documentary-making at its best, not pretending to be journalism, but still playing a crucial role in telling stories that otherwise wouldn't make the front page.
That rare comedy that will appeal to the whole family, as it indulges in all the dreams of fairy-tale romance while making a few 21st-century adjustments.
An absorbing, occasionally hallucinatory disquisition on how Dylan has brilliantly eluded his audience's projections.
The Life of Reilly pays fitting homage to a man who deserves to be remembered for much more than just trading double-entendres with Brett Somers on The Match Game.
For the uninitiated, Demme's film provides an absorbing, if largely hagiographic, portrait of a man who has redefined the idea of post-presidential retirement.
Sean Penn sings a powerful and poetic hymn to America with "Into the Wild," his sweeping, sensitive and deeply affecting adaptation of Jon Krakauer's best-selling book.

A vivid portrait of a society in the midst of wrenching change, but it transcends its immediate context to become a thoughtful, even unforgettable, chamber piece, performed with exquisite subtlety by two fine actresses.
Overplotting and a particularly ugly turn make this adaptation of Dirk Wittenborn's novel less a meditation on how the rich are different than a bland coming-of-age procedural.
Nancy Drew manages to navigate the era of cellphones and Mean Girls with retro nostalgia and wholesomeness, making it a rare girl-powered outing for tweens in an otherwise guy-centric summer.
[An] intimate, urgent and wildly imaginative indictment of post-colonial economic policies in Africa.

Italian director Emanuele Crialese has infused the age-old plot with dazzling visual style, dollops of magical realism and profound emotional truth that infuse what we think we know with new verve and resonance.
A taut, meticulously crafted police procedural. Part thriller, part melodrama, A Mighty Heart recalls last year's United 93 in its technical prowess and artistry, and in its harrowing emotional arc.

At a time when the action genre has come to be dominated by sleek, matte surfaces and set-'em-and-forget-'em computerized effects, Live Free or Die Hard seeks to remind viewers of the simple, nostalgic pleasures of watching stuff get blown up.
Evening is a terribly refined, painstakingly composed study in aristocratic angst that audiences will be hard-pressed to believe a word of.

It's easy to see why [director] Dellal had trouble turning the camera off, especially when confronted with a startling and sad plot twist. Viewers are urged to grab an aisle seat, the better to dance when the music moves them -- as it surely will.
movie_title: When the Road Bends: Tales of a Gypsy Caravan (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Harrowing, controlled and diabolically self-assured, Joshua leaves filmgoers teetering on their own emotional precipice, wondering just where pathos ends and pathology begins.

That such a masterful depiction of American heroism and can-do spirit has been created by a German art film director known for considerably darker visions of obsession is an irony Herzog no doubt finds delicious.
A welcome chance to see Posey at her flighty, edgy best. Is there an actress alive better able to convey the neuroses and self-doubts of the typical over-educated, under-challenged American woman?
The cast is superb, especially the young actors who portray Vitus; [Teo] Gheorghiu is a real-life piano prodigy, lending an extra frisson to the intoxicating music that plays throughout the film.
Inspired by a real-life couple now living in Paris, David & Layla is suffused with the warmth and passion of filmmaker Jay Jonroy, whose own family was victimized under Saddam Hussein.
The Ten never breaks out of jejune noodling and into something truly provocative.
Ironically, Lavoe's sad story serves mostly to remind viewers that Lopez is still the dazzling force of nature that burst onto the screen a scant 10 years ago.
A supernatural fantasy action adventure whose combination of whimsy and gothic melodrama seems to have been cobbled together from focus groups held at Comic-Con and Renaissance fairs.
A film that serves as a kind of manic tour through French film history. Ah, l'amour! Ah, le cinema!
Greg Mottola executes Superbad with his characteristically light touch, even if it's used in the service of filthy sight gags, endless profanity and an inordinate obsession with bodily fluids.
A throwback to 1970s blaxploitation flicks, with a Latin accent, Illegal Tender would be a brassy, sassy guilty pleasure if it were more, well, pleasurable.
An extravagant and thoroughly irresistible story of intrigue, romance, comedy and artistic inspiration.
Right at Your Door is a tick-tock of post-apocalyptic paranoia and moral ambiguity that would have made for some taut psychodrama on The Twilight Zone.

Across the Universe, in which Taymor shoehorns, contorts and otherwise bullies some of the Fab Four's greatest hits into a vapid Hollywood musical, is the kind of project that must have looked great on paper. On screen, eh, not so much.

It's an old story, but [the directors] infuse it with terrific wit and energy, structuring Surf's Up like a mock documentary and doing a remarkable job of approximating vintage film stock. It's cool but not too cool, and cute but not too cute.
Even considering Black's prodigious talents, Pick gets tiresome way too quickly.
movie_title: Tenacious D in The Pick of Destiny (2006)

movie_review_blurb: There's not much here for anyone who isn't a die-hard, unreconstructed chop-socky junkie.

Purists will howl at the liberties Shainberg has taken with the facts, but there's a bravery to Fur, an uncompromising commitment to its narrow focus -- of one woman's creative birth -- that rhymes with Arbus's own artistic courage.
movie_title: Fur: An Imaginary Portrait of Diane Arbus (2006)

movie_review_blurb: An engrossing piece of social history, a lively, astonishingly well-documented excavation of that period between June 1969 and June 1981 when gay men in New York experienced a bacchanalian burst of sexual liberation.
Just when you thought Doogal set the lowest bar possible for a dog comedy, here comes The Shaggy Dog, a pointless remake of the 1959 Disney classic.
This is an example of a writer and director working in perfect harness, with Reed smoothly ratcheting up the story's suspense and Greene speculating on his cardinal theme of moral ambiguity.
Fake or not, Unknown White Male doesn't live up to its tantalizing potential.
The film ends with a moving and surprisingly sophisticated meditation on the definition of moral duty.
Ask the Dust is one of the most eagerly awaited cinematic projects of 2006, which may be why it lands with such a curious thud.
Preachy, condescending and shockingly naive.
A piece of well-crafted righteous indignation.
movie_title: CSA: The Confederate States of America (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The film's unforgettable stars are the beauty academy's students, women who have survived tribal warfare, Soviet invasion, Muslim tyranny, American bombs, patriarchal families and even Western good intentions with extraordinary grace and fortitude.
Aquamarine is better than nothing for its woefully underserved audience.
A riotous, rapturous explosion of sound and color.
Like all the Dardennes' films, L'Enfant is a vivid, Dickensian report from the most dispossessed precincts of society.
The most crucial element of Mountain Patrol's success is Duo's portrayal of Ri Tai, a tough, terse hero who could have sprung fully formed from the imagination of Akira Kurosawa or Sergio Leone.

... this by turns funny, affecting tale pays homage not just to one young person's determination and character but to all those parents, teachers and myriad guardian angels who in real life instill young people with the love of language ...
... derivative and overeager to both shock and please.
United 93 may be the best movie I ever hated.
Director J.J. Abrams, creator of such TV hits as Alias and Lost, makes a reasonably impressive feature debut with the best installment of the series.
Though Watt's emphasis on coincidence and fate seems strained at times, Look Both Ways is rich in dreamy summer atmosphere and deadpan wit.
Reflects surprisingly assured filmmaking sensibilities, especially when it comes to portraying the foibles and preoccupations of young women at loose ends.
Hawks and doves alike should be grateful to Zeiger for preserving a fascinating piece of American cultural history that the vets recount here.
Reeks of a project desperate for edgy credibility.
movie_title: The Heart Is Deceitful Above All Things (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The film lives up to its hype with a style, swagger and substance that will appeal not just to the fanboys (and girls) but to their uninitiated friends as well.
What could have been an unusually smart police procedural becomes a sprawling, overwrought melodrama that itself morphs into a sort of spiritual romance.
The eight canine stars of Eight Below pull their weight literally and figuratively in this lively dog-in-jep adventure from Disney.
That rare film that merges the personal and political without sacrificing restraint or intellectual honesty.
Darwin's Nightmare is many things, including an environmental cautionary tale, a critique of globalization and a portrait of a community, country and continent in deep crisis.

Curley and Harrison have created a surprisingly tedious, overblown defense of a sport that, while ushering in the era of "extreme" games, doesn't boast the cinematic potential or charismatic stars of its cousins on the asphalt and aquatic waves.
In director and co-writer Dani Levy's capable hands, Go for Zucker is less a comedy of religious manners than of Cold War nostalgia on par with 2003's Good Bye, Lenin!

The film is an important historical document, an eerily prescient antiwar plea and a dazzling example of moviemaking at its most iconographically potent. But at its best, it is the eloquent, unforgettable tale of profound moral reckoning.
A sweeping, solemn, self-serious chronicle of their relationship over several decades.
It's fun, and that's fine.
If Tucker's road map often feels a little too confining and the screwball comedy too contrived, he can take credit for introducing viewers to a character they have almost certainly never met before.
The patronizing, gratuitous sentimentality undermines what could and should have been a simple story of courage and beauty.
As an intimate glimpse into an otherwise hidden world, it's admittedly absorbing, but the subjects merit a more rigorous portrait.

Well, I just had this weird feeling that things weren't going to work out for them. But even though you can see it coming, this director Kevin Reynolds just makes the whole thing drag on and on and on and on.
It's one helluva story, and if this moving, and even thrilling little movie finally brings Haskins and a truly great American sports story to light, then three cheers and hooray.
[Writer-director] Bardwell offers a cheerful, if sometimes strenuously earnest, take on a subject that seems overdue for a lighthearted touch.
Humor and warmth abound.
Luong is radiant as Linh, and the rest of the accomplished cast give First Morning the ring of truth, even at its most awkwardly melodramatic.
It succeeds, if unevenly.
Manages to present scientific inquiry as an emotional journey, during which two exquisitely designed machines go from being gears and hinges to the embodiment of our best hopes and dreams.

Fateless is an extraordinary film, not just for its harrowing attention to detail of life within the concentration camps, but for the equal place of privilege it gives to life before and after World War II.
When a Stranger Calls has been remade -- with undistinguished if inoffensive results -- by Simon West, who is quickly becoming a reliable purveyor of Hollywood's dreckiest dreck.
The Pink Panther ees, how you say, ze real dog.
A film that might have been a dry exercise in earnest nonfiction filmmaking becomes a soaring, artistically complex testament to survival, character and hope.
The most controversial thriller of the year turns out to be about as exciting as watching your parents play Sudoku.
A revisionist western that brings its own brand of sanguinary honesty to the genre.
[Director] Ratner makes a hash of the story and characters his predecessor brought to such complex, sympathetic life, delivering a pumped-up exercise in mayhem, carnage and blunt-force trauma.
A charming, if limited, romantic comedy that examines post-collegiate angst with easy, unself-conscious humor.
The climactic scenes possess an irresistible charm, as each wedding turns out to be just perfect.
With a slick visual style similar to Monster House, Open Season trots out tropes that recent animated classics have done with more wit and smarts.

Often funny (just listen to Becky fulminate against Harry Potter), but it's also a scary, sobering inside look at the attempts of an increasingly powerful group to erode the separation of church and state.

This chiaroscuro thriller is more visually arresting than narratively convincing, and as the police procedural unfolds, what might have been a sly cautionary tale, a la this summer's A Scanner Darkly, becomes merely procedural.

Readers tempted to write off that episode as yet another paranoid fantasy of The Left should take heed: The U.S. vs. John Lennon includes the firsthand testimony of the spies themselves, from apostate FBI agents to the unapologetic G. Gordon Liddy.

The Departed, which screenwriter William Monahan cleverly adapted from the Hong Kong thriller Infernal Affairs, crackles right along, stopping only long enough for Scorsese's signature bursts of explosive violence.

Rarely has an actress exuded such blank nothingness as Simpson, a one-woman vapid delivery system who sucks the energy and joy out of every scene she's in, like some freakishly well-endowed black hole.
Pulses with the honesty and spontaneity of early films by Martin Scorsese and Spike Lee.
movie_title: A Guide to Recognizing Your Saints (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The premise -- a roundelay of New Yorkers looking for connection, or to escape it -- feels tired.
A valuable chronicle of a brief and snarling musical movement.
The kind of movie whose dialogue mostly hews to the rhythms of 'like, you know, whatever' but then occasionally throws in a word such as 'puissance.' And, like, it totally works.

Coppola brilliantly conjures the young queen's insular world, in which she was both isolated and claustrophobically scrutinized. While not celebrating Marie Antoinette's reign, Coppola clearly sympathizes with a girl who was less heedless than naive.
Okay, I'll say it: If you see only one magic-at-the-turn-of-the-century movie this year, make it this one.
Becomes an excruciating exercise in gothic excess and progressively more disgusting imagery.
There's nothing particularly objectionable about the film (other than its inert movie-of-the-week structure) until Walsch takes his God-spokesman role too far in the final act.
As skillful an artist as (director Gabriel) Range clearly is, he has gone to an awful lot of trouble to make a painfully obvious point about threats to civil liberties in a post-9/11 world.

A perfect combination of slapstick and satire that manages to appeal to our basest common denominators while brilliantly skewering racism, anti-Semitism, sexism and that peculiarly American affliction: we're-number-one-ism.
movie_title: Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Flushed Away, Aardman's first computer-generated cartoon, does away with the clay but leaves the craft and emotion intact, resulting in a film that earns its place among the Aardman classics.

Scott and Crowe, who last worked together on Gladiator, should have stuck with the togas; Crowe runs the emotional gamut from bored to perplexed to just plain miserable in a romantic comedy that is neither romantic nor comic.
A vivid, poetic evocation of life in post-invasion Iraq that works both as impressionistic collage and candid portraiture.

[The film] may contain as many riffs on ego, self-deception and corporate greed as Guest's directorial debut, but it also possesses something rarely seen from the director: a shocking degree of unforgiving misanthropy.
Director Frank Popper has made a lively, engaging nail-biter of a film that recalls The War Room in its candor, intimacy and breathless pace.
It's a sprawling experiment in philosophical time travel and metaphysical noodling. And it's an earnest, magnificent wreck.

The film ultimately becomes too contrived to be anything but a fleeting diversion, but kudos to these emerging filmmakers for daring to make something a little bit different and, for the most part, intriguing.
... a lugubrious tutorial on the importance of being a winner.
As he does with his still photography, Turnley achieves a breathtaking level of intimacy in La Tropical. which swirls and dances just as sensually as the undulating bodies at the club.

It's the moral journey of Nolte's character that is the real story in Clean, but Assayas instead focuses on the manipulative habits of an addict, resulting in a mannered study of narcissism and self-pity.

Follows the youngsters over the course of a tumultuous year, during which time Cuesta and screenwriter Anthony Cipriano succeed in making the audience care desperately whether they're okay and whether the adults in their lives do the right thing.
Combines nonstop action with an absorbing story to become a classic on par with Hoosiers and Hoop Dreams -- with the best of He Got Game and Glory Road thrown in for good measure.
Warm, lively and organized around an ingenious structural conceit.
What it does do, with grim and often gruesome honesty, is show the realities of war to a public that has been largely shielded from its cost.
What might have been a fascinating, intimate portrait turns into something much less compelling when Clark tries to impose a sex-and-action-packed narrative on the proceedings.
Bloodless where it should be bold, precious where it should be perceptive and irritating where it should be inspiring.
Artistically, You, Me and Dupree is a mess. Technically, it's an abomination. Spiritually, it's a void. Commercially, it'll probably be a big hit.
Clerks II finds Smith up to the profane, raunchy, profoundly humanist mischief of which he alone is the master.
Monster House is an eyesore.

Despite doing its best to jiggle, giggle and ogle its way into a niche somewhere between Heathers and American Pie, it becomes just another forgettable pastiche of sight gags and pop-culture references.
With its self-conscious literary references and trendy settings, Trust the Man quickly begins to feel hopelessly derivative of other, better movies.
The Illusionist is that rarity in the dog days of summer, a movie made for grown-ups, which is what makes it that much more disappointing.
There's too much slow-mo and too many music cues, but there's a low-key buzz to Wahlberg's scenes with Greg Kinnear, who plays newcomer coach Dick Vermeil.
Wins you over even as it dares you to keep watching.
Nearly every scene rings with its own ragged truth.

Although audiences will admire the film's do-it-yourself energy and commitment, Poster Boy finally collapses of its own contrived weight, deflating just when it should soar into madcap -- or at least thoughtful -- satire.
Rather than an indictment of depravity, the movie quickly becomes a particularly cynical example of it.
Pereira goes in for lots of time shifts and split screens, piling on the contrivances like so many costume baubles when a single string of pearls would do.
In the almost spookily capable hands of 34-year-old director Joe Wright, the film version of Atonement has achieved that to which every literary adaptation should aspire.

Visually dazzling, epic in its sweep and deeply romantic in its sensibility, The House of Sand is one of those films whose images and ideas linger long after the lights come on, having been burned into the viewer's consciousness.
What Would Jesus Buy? is must-see viewing for anyone who thinks of Christmas as just a mall and its night visitors.

Even something as modest as Paranoid Park manages to reflect Van Sant's greatest strengths as an artist: his seemingly limitless fluency with his chosen medium and his willingness to tell even the oldest stories in bold new ways.
[The script] hasn't been written as much as stamped out like so many cheap Christmas knickknacks that will be on the clearance shelf come Dec. 26.

If you stick with this wistful, fitfully funny little trip, you will be rewarded with a movie that makes up in warmth, humanism and self-effacing modesty what it lacks in crackerjack pacing and epic pop-historical grandeur.
If Bullock in her comfort zone is a thing of real, if modest pleasure, watching as she contorts herself into a role that's all wrong for her is singularly excruciating.
As a filmmaker seeking to master the art of satire without cynicism, Bobcat Goldthwait might be one sick puppy -- but he's also the sweetest one we've got.
Soderbergh is a good listener, too, always alert to the myriad ways his characters reveal, conceal and finally betray themselves in thought, word and deed.
[Jonze has] achieved with the cinematic medium what Sendak did with words and pictures: He's grasped something true and terrifying about love at its most unconditional and voracious.
The Horse Boy is a lovely, amazing, wonderfully provocative film.

Mostly, A Serious Man succeeds because it engages questions worth asking. What is integrity? Does our atavistic need for stories illuminate the meaning of life or further obfuscate it? What does it mean to be good and how are we to achieve it?

By far the most powerful element is N'Dour's lone voice, a thing of high, pure beauty that feels at once ancient and new. When he sings, an otherwise earnestly conventional film becomes a vehicle of incantatory power.
movie_title: Youssou Ndour: I Bring What I Love (2009)

movie_review_blurb: This refreshing alternative to the usual potted biopic provides an absorbing look at a singular, steely determination as it was forged and annealed, long before it made itself known to the world.
These pitch-perfect moments, as well as Giamatti's performance as an artist driven to a personal and creative brink, make Cold Souls, if not always coherent, at least compelling.
Good Hair, directed by longtime Rock collaborator Jeff Stilson, is such a rollicking, thoroughly entertaining ride that it's easy to take for granted just how easy Rock makes it look.
A clear-eyed portrait of a highly charged chapter in Germany's history, a history that once again proves rewarding fodder for an alert artistic imagination.
movie_title: Anonyma - Eine Frau in Berlin (A Woman in Berlin) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The sense of emotional detachment keeps things feeling smooth and low-key, but, as is clear in the film's last few scenes, the playful tone shades into the simply trivial, which in the setting doesn't quite play.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Surely qualifies as the most painful, poetic and improbably beautiful film of the year.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: While it's possible to be enormously entertained and moved by The Blind Side, it's also possible to harbor a twinge of misgiving.
Like a jumpy, coke-fueled Pied Piper, Cage takes viewers to the very precipice of depraved self-abasement, while preserving just enough self-conscious humor to keep from tumbling in.
movie_title: Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The Road possesses undeniable sweep and a grim kind of grandeur, but it ultimately plays like a zombie movie with literary pretensions.
Adds yet another wry, carefully composed bibelot to the cabinet of curios that defines the Anderson oeuvre.
Up in the Air is a timeless movie that's utterly of its time -- a movie of humor, heart and mind.
Everybody should see Everybody's Fine. But one piece of advice: Phone home first.
A beguiling little film that, with deceptive restraint and forthrightness, opens up worlds of roiling, contradictory emotions.

If parents feel like they've seen much of Shorts before, its celebration of mayhem and restless, thrill-seeking vibe will absorb young viewers, especially as the boredom of late summer begins to set in.
movie_title: Shorts: The Adventures of the Wishing Rock (2009)

movie_review_blurb: For all its visual bravura and occasional bursts of antic inspiration, it feels trivial, the work of a kid who can't stop grabbing his favorite shiny plaything.

Soul Power turns out to be an unusually resonant time capsule, one that weaves together theatrics, musicianship, cosmopolitanism and sharp political critique in a vibrant look-back that's at once celebratory and wistful.
Hollywood loves the heroics of good intentions, but this is that rare movie that is just as interested in the road to hell.

Every once in a while, for reasons as random as a Hollywood executive's taste or an economic meltdown, a perfectly decent movie slips through the cracks, never receives a theatrical release and is relegated to the purgatory called straight-to-DVD.
With the moving, absorbing drama Sugar, Boden and Fleck not only avoid the sophomore slump, they demolish it, delivering a film of rare intelligence, beauty and compassion.
It all makes for an absorbing, mischievously amusing yarn, whose climax unfolds with unexpected emotional force.
If the world is going to hell in any number of handbaskets -- as Judge so acutely demonstrates that it is -- you might as well hitch a ride in his.
A movie that, against all odds, has miraculously resurrected a wheezing but beloved franchise.
Bahrani's new movie, Goodbye Solo, offers further proof that he is one of the best reasons to keep going to the movies.
Pixar has done it again, in every best way possible.
Feels like a welcome respite from the false happily-ever-afters of most mainstream movies.
Just looking at the poster for The Proposal, a by-the-numbers romantic comedy starring Sandra Bullock and Ryan Reynolds, tells you exactly how it's all gonna go down.
This absorbing film looks terrific and does a superb job of making its case that our current food ways are drastically out of whack.
An adaptation that, although departing dramatically from such key elements as the book's ending, will please fans.
This toxic, contemptuous, unforgivably unfunny bagatelle finds Allen at his most misanthropically one-note.
Brüno is no Borat.

The Hurt Locker is about Iraq in the same way that Paths of Glory was about World War I or Full Metal Jacket was about Vietnam -- which is to say, utterly and not at all. The Hurt Locker is a great movie, period.
In its vivid, suspenseful depiction of a high-stakes competition for prize money and the honor of being named Afghanistan's top singer, Afghan Star goes much deeper.

Surely writers David Leslie Johnson and Alex Mace deserve their own circle of hell for thinking up the story, which moves with breathtaking cynicism from disturbing to grotesque to perverse to ludicrous.
It's that rare mainstream Hollywood movie that feels genuinely spontaneous, unafraid to keep the audience just a little bit confounded and off-balance.
Streep and Tucci enjoy a terrific, infectious onscreen chemistry as soul mates for whom food and entertaining were part of one long, sensuous continuum.

Unlike the sublime (500) Days of Summer, which also had to do with young romance, ambivalence and rethinking the notion of happy endings, Paper Heart never transcends its twee, hyper-self-aware niche.
The audience will no doubt laugh on cue as The Goods hits its marks with dutiful predictability, but they shouldn't be surprised if they come to feel like they've been had.
movie_title: The Goods: Live Hard, Sell Hard (2009)

movie_review_blurb: You can exhale now: The Princess and the Frog is a triumph on every one of the myriad levels it has been asked to succeed on.
Based on a hit BBC miniseries, State of Play features a handsome production and terrific performances from its aforementioned stars.
Morgan Freeman doesn't play Mandela as much as inhabit the man, in a performance that seems to embody the very transcendence that Mandela himself has come to stand for.
The Young Victoria may impart copious amounts of detail about its fascinating protagonists, but it's not a mere tutorial: It's a heady, thoroughly transporting plunge.
Hot Tub Time Machine simmers right along like so many Jacuzzi bubbles popping with a carefully calibrated mix of sight gags, sex jokes and baby boomer references.
If filmgoers ultimately feel bogged down in its densely layered fable and allegory, it's a spectacular thicket to get lost in.
Toe to Toe deserves credit for delving into the rich dynamics of interracial friendship and teenaged social tectonics. And it features some terrific acting.
While Jett and Currie emerge as blurry, half-formed characters, Shannon's Fowley brings the contradictions the Runaways embodied into sharp, biting focus.
McPherson has managed a rare hat trick in genre mash-up, fashioning a deeply absorbing movie that balances horror, romance, comedy and observant humanism with surprising finesse.

An absorbing story of the unlikely intersection of an unrequited love affair and an unresolved crime, this taut thriller features some bravura cinematic moments and memorable performances from an exceptionally attractive cast of players.
movie_title: The Secret in Their Eyes (El Secreto de Sus Ojos) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Suggested subtitle: Iron Man, You Just Got Served.

If for the most part Death at a Funeral is as tame as the tasteful parlor where most of its action takes place, it manages to explode one taboo, in casting mostly black actors in roles originally played by whites.
Exit Through the Gift Shop offers an absorbing glimpse of a bracingly subversive slice of the culture, as well as some tantalizing images of Banksy at work.
The movie has the easy, unforced feel of the temporary timeout in life that Roger himself has embarked on. The script is full of funny, observant lines.
Through vivid archival material and voice-overs, the filmmakers create moving vignettes that, taken together, form a fascinating primer on nonviolence as a political force and discipline.

Babies is a mesmerizing and weirdly manipulative experience, combining wide-eyed innocence and shrewd cultural commentary as it chronicles the folkways and familial rites of four starkly different societies.
Michael Caine delivers a stunning performance in Harry Brown, a rancid little revenge fantasy that probably doesn't deserve him.
Please Give is one of those movies that can be enjoyed simply for its funny portraits of human foibles and fumbling grasps at intimacy -- but it's also deceivingly profound.
Ghobadi has emerged as a filmmaker whose gift for poetic realism was only equaled by an unerring sense of precisely when and how to break the viewer's heart.
movie_title: No One Knows About Persian Cats (Les Chats Persans) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: With Mother and Child, Garca brings his finely calibrated sense of drama to the subject of adoption, which he handles with characteristic restraint and insight -- at least until the film's maudlin, too-pat finale.
An enervated, crass and gruesomely caricatured trip to nowhere [that] seems conceived primarily to find new and more cynical ways to abuse the loyalty of its audience.
A thoroughly repulsive science fiction-horror flick that slicks up its B-movie tawdriness with high-gloss production values and two otherwise classy stars.

Micmacs ends with an elaborate set piece celebrating illusion at its most seductive, but the movie itself winds up feeling like just that: an exercise in surface tricks and sleight of hand, without much emotion or warmth to give it more meaning.
The musical sequences are the best thing about Walk the Line, and luckily they are plentiful.
Often playing like it has been jury-rigged from bits and pieces of a longer, smarter movie, Iron Man 2 seems chiefly intended as a placeholder for its next dozen or so sequels.
The Art of the Steal ultimately gets mired in the legal weeds, a snare made all the more frustrating by the fact that the move is a fait accompli.
Chloe descends into a preposterous third act that, by any measure, qualifies as a disaster. But it's proof of Egoyan's skill that the film works for as long as it does.
Funny? Scary? Entirely logical? It all depends on your point of view, of course, and What's the Matter With Kansas? isn't likely to move viewers one way or another.
How fitting that Firth should carry A Single Man, a movie of quiet but potent emotional power, perfectly suited to his singular gifts.
It's a film within a film about a film within a film, and seems to lose layers of authenticity with each iteration, finally becoming a profoundly alienating experience.

Shot through with a bold, extravagant generosity of spirit, this journey behind the literal and figurative looking glass marks a gratifying return to form for Gilliam, whose recent films haven't quite lived up to his capacities.
From The Catcher in the Rye to Rushmore, it's a story we've seen in better versions before.
Tone is the first thing sacrificed in this shapeless, overlong, mawkishly muddled pop-up illustration of a movie.

It's a surprisingly compelling way to build a sense of encroaching dread, delving into a banal, deceptively featureless world where the slightest bureaucratic blip or slip could change someone's life forever.
Vaughan has a tendency to underline, italicize and boldface the emotion when no such emphasis is needed.
For a movie that clearly seeks to bring Darwin to life, Creation spends an awful lot of time wallowing in death.
It's sometimes difficult to discern whether the filmmakers are dissecting male bonding, ritualized aggression and sexual anxiety or celebrating it.
If the operatic emotional pitch ultimately proves unsustainable (not to mention tiresome), the film is full of captivating details.

Jarvis, whom the director reportedly discovered at an Essex train station, is nothing less than a revelation in a performance that is tender, spiky and utterly fearless in its physical and emotional range.
The White Ribbon lunges hungrily for serious art-film credibility. Don't be fooled.
It pulses with the suspense and momentum of a sleek thriller -- a wily caper flick that just happens to revolve around one of the most crucial chapters in recent American history.
movie_title: Most Dangerous Man in America: Daniel Ellsberg and the Pentagon Papers (2009)

movie_review_blurb: As Shutter Island proceeds -- mostly as a series of speeches and set pieces -- what is meant to be mysterious and unsettling becomes just plain incomprehensible.
While its themes of revenge, mutual resentment and grim fatalism offer little hope for a ready solutions, the movie itself testifies to the power of creative collaboration in finding common ground.

From the chic austerity of the Langs' undisclosed location to the gradually revealed nexus between academia, politics and corporate influence, The Ghost Writer offers an unusually astute glimpse of power at its most alluring and corrosive.
Even considering the liberties Burton has taken with the original text, it's tempting to think that Carroll himself would consider him an altogether frabjous match.

Fans of Peace's books should be satisfied by their treatment here, although it bears asking just how many more serial killers, tortured cops and pretentious, fetishistic acts of violence the film audience can withstand.
Although these aren't characters with whom filmgoers will have an instinctive rooting interest, Rahim and Arestrup imbue them with fascinating nuances and, in Rahim's case, surprising vulnerability.
A jangly, noisy, compulsively restless thriller on a par with the Bourne movies, shot through with political critique.
A lyrical and loud anthem to endurance and sheer chops.
An ambitious, fully immersive cinematic experience.

Is there anything more tiresome than watching people play video games? Seth Gordon's documentary The King of Kong: A Fistful of Quarters answers that question with a decisive yes: watching a movie about people playing video games.
movie_title: The King of Kong: A Fistful of Quarters (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Thanks to an exceptionally deft touch, Mottola manages to capture the absurdity and anguish of young adulthood, while never sacrificing meaning on the altar of crude humor.
Writer-director Veit Helmer creates a wildly imaginative world worthy of Gabriel Garca Mrquez at his most playful, drenching it in vivid color and a Slavic sense of bleak humor.
[Director] Lee makes a spirited and persuasive case for break dancing, not only as an art form of strength, beauty, discipline and instinct, but as a means of transcending caste and culture.
Even as the derivative roots of "Nim's Island" are clearly visible, kids will no doubt vicariously enjoy Nim's adventures and Edenic existence.
It's impossible to tell whether the film's ending is happy because it's happy or because it's ending.
The Visitor gives viewers a perceptive, deeply personal take on the timeless immigrant narrative, in which the most epic journey is finally one of self-discovery.
Audiences alive to the modest charms of its take on female friendship will be rewarded with at least a few quiet chuckles.
Uma Thurman delivers a mesmerizing performance in The Life Before Her Eyes, a film that, once seen and fully digested, exerts the same haunting pull as the shattering events it chronicles.

Toggling between Stark's impish goatee and Iron Man's full-metal body condom, and amid so many generic fireballs, kill shots and earsplitting thumps, bumps and crunches, the film finally collapses under its own weight.
A frenetic, densely layered, narratively scrambled blob of moviemaking that will leave viewers alternately baffled and sensorially stunned.

Prince Caspian, like its predecessor, delivers sweeping, swashbuckling action in a handsome production, albeit one that leaves viewers feeling quite pummeled by the end of its nearly 2 1/2 -hour running time.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Although [director] Kutzera does a great job of cinematic excavation and editing, Military Intelligence and You! never manages to overcome its tone of glib condescension and soar to Strangelovian heights.
It's bad enough that writer-director David Ross indulges in the very perverse kind of Lolita-tinged titillation the film pretends to lament, but then he ties everything up with an oh-well shrug.
Judged by the standards of its original medium, the movie version succeeds just as well, cramming what used to take a whole season into a nearly 2 1/2 -hour marathon of men, misery and Manolos.

The question is why the time, talent and treasure of such energetic and even gifted artists have been marshaled in such a disgusting and trivial genre exercise and what viewers are supposed to get out of it. Isn't life hard enough?

Italian director Dario Argento is revered by hard-core horror fans for his gothic, over-the-top thrillers, but even the patience of his most devoted followers will be sorely tested by Mother of Tears: The Third Mother.
movie_title: Mother of Tears: The Third Mother (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A classic comic-book hero quest that, while not entirely novel, hews to its own rules and conventions with dignity and artfulness.
"Everybody touch somebody," he says as he opens the band prayer. He does. They do. Amen.
The Edge of Heaven is the movie Babel so badly wanted to be.
movie_title: Auf der Anderen Seite (The Edge of Heaven) (On the Other Side) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A vivid, nuanced and sweetly forgiving study in moral ambiguity.
For critics of the war with an appetite for red meat, War, Inc. will prove filling, if not quite completely nourishing.
Jolie, thin as a wraith and as still as alabaster, reigns supreme as the queen of great screen objects, and Freeman has one of the film's funniest (if profane) lines.

Provides a diverting portrait of modern-day Israel, as the filmmakers eschew history, politics and religion to focus instead on more intimate and universal issues of fate, loss and the longing to connect.
Here, Apatow produces a script co-written by Seth Rogen that, although not particularly objectionable, seems a pale shadow of such hugely popular watersheds as The 40-Year-Old Virgin and Superbad.

Thanks to the uncommonly shrewd judgment of screenwriter Ligiah Villalobos and director Patricia Riggen, both newcomers, Under the Same Moon never feels like rank exploitation, even as it steadily aims for the emotional jugular.
An inert, sloppily written melodrama as grim and featureless as its frozen Midwestern setting.
A film of exhilarating, redemptive humanity, conveying an enduring sense of hope.

One of those genre-defying hybrids that are sometimes called dramedies, The Savages tiptoes along a particularly fraught emotional tightrope, balancing observant humor and deep sadness with uncommon grace.

Thanks to Bauby's courageous and honest writing, and Schnabel's poetic interpretation, what could have been a portrait of impotence and suffering becomes a lively exploration of consciousness and a soaring ode to liberation.
movie_title: The Diving Bell and the Butterfly (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Walk Hard is one of those fish-in-a-barrel comedies that mine a rich comedic vein but manage to come up with few genuine gems.
movie_title: Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A rich, mostly tender fairy tale.
movie_title: The Water Horse: Legend of the Deep (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Paul Thomas Anderson becomes California's certified cinematic poet laureate with There Will Be Blood.

As tired as First Sunday is, and as shamelessly as it grovels for laughs, there's a hint of sweetness, and [director] Talbert clearly has a feel for Baltimore, where most of it was affectionately shot.
A romantic comedy that -- despite her [Star Katherine Heigl] undeniable, apple-cheeked appeal -- sags like a day-old bouquet.
It's not that much fun.
As Untraceable descends into the progressively more perverted territory, it begins to practice the very hypocrisy it condemns in its audience, engaging in the rancid voyeurism it pretends to abhor.

For film connoisseurs who are interested in how far the medium can go in depicting human stories with realism at its most confrontational and even discomfiting, 4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days will provide a bracing breath of fresh cinematic air.
For the uninitiated? Man, it's a bummer.
It's that rare genre picture targeted to teens and young adults that suffers from underkill.

Such a far-fetched shaggy-dog yarn borders on the patronizing. But Gondry's belief in community-based, handmade, DIY culture is infectious, and his cry against big-box homogenization (fewer choices, more copies) is a noble one.

Trudging nobly under a mantle of impeccably earnest intentions and a fussy, too-quaint-by-half production design, Honeydripper lags and drags to its utterly predictable end. There's not a spark of spontaneity or soul about it.
With luck, filmgoers who discover this gem about an Egyptian police band stranded in a small Israeli town will make it the must-see movie of the season.

Filmgoers expecting My Big Fat Lebanese Waxing are in for a bigger treat: Nadine Labaki, who wrote and directed the film, possesses an astute instinct for restraint that makes Caramel smarter ans more poignantthan the average chick flick.

Chicago 10 not only brings to life one of the sorriest chapters in American cultural and political history, but breathes new life into a film genre that usually has all the imagination and verve of a visit to Madame Tussauds.
After a particularly dour Oscar season, the jolly romantic romp Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day sparkles like a rhinestone in the muck.
movie_title: Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day (2008)

movie_review_blurb: One part Joseph Campbell hero quest, one part multi-culti morality tale, one part live-action Flintstones cartoon, 10,000 B.C. is finally every part just plain nuts.
Fighting for Life is essential viewing at a time when, five years on, the war's human cost is still too often mired in partisan rhetoric and administration spin.
Finding Amanda has its wispy charms, including a funny scene when the ecstasy Taylor pops begins to kick in, and later when he encounters a pimp with showbiz aspirations.
McQueen has taken the raw materials of filmmaking and committed an act of great art.

As he has done in all his movies, from creature features such as Mimic to serious dramas such as Pan's Labyrinth, del Toro creates unforgettable images, filled with color, texture, lyricism and horror.

Mamma Mia! presents itself as a piece of clever counter-programming to this summer's surfeit of pounding, effects-driven comic-book movies. But filmgoers eager to sample its sunny, synth-pop pleasures are likely to feel just as bludgeoned.

Once in a while, a movie arrives at such a perfect moment, its message and meaning so finely tuned to the current zeitgeist, that it seems less a cinematic event than a cosmic convergence, willed into being by a once-in-a-lifetime alignment of the stars.
Solemn, sober and efficient, The Day the Earth Stood Still gets the job done and moves on.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A taut, high-stakes game of cat-and-mouse drives the absorbing psychological thriller Doubt.
Nearly 40 years after its initial release, Francois Truffaut's The Wild Child (L'Enfant Sauvage) still manages to cast its haunting, poetic spell.
As undeniably tasteful as The Reader is, it's also an absorbing and finally moving account of how one man comes to terms with both history and his story.

If you can survive the F-bombs and the near-constant ethnic invective, Gran Torino is not to be missed, if only as the gutsy, thoroughly unexpected valedictory of an icon fully willing to spend every bit of his considerable capital.
Benjamin Button is little more than Gump by way of Dorian Gray. It plays too safe when it should be letting its freak flag fly.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Sam Mendes's spiritually depleted film exerts an undeniable pull as its beautiful, doomed protagonists navigate the ennui of adult life. Revolutionary Road provides an apt bookend to a holiday season drenched in fatalistic gloom.
Predictable, lazy and as overprocessed as Kate Hudson's hair, this thoroughly joyless movie also possesses a deep nasty streak, making it loathsome when it might have been merely annoying.
A wildly ambitious, luridly indulgent spectacle of romance, action, melodrama and historic revisionism, Australia is windy, overblown, utterly preposterous and insanely entertaining.
Not Easily Broken exerts an unmistakable appeal, thanks to an absorbing story and fine performances from Morris Chestnut and Taraji P. Henson.
Craig and Schreiber are terrific as the slightly thuggish Bielskis, and they're joined by an able supporting cast that includes Jamie Bell and the wonderful Mia Wasikowska.
The aesthetics of Inkheart are part of what make it such a surprisingly enjoyable experience to watch.
The story about five women navigating male treachery is so busy getting all its talking points in that it leaves no room for recognizable life.
movie_title: He's Just Not That Into You (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Garbled at times, the movie still hums along with attractive, smooth efficiency.
Maybe if he [director Wayne Kramer] had kept Crossing Over simpler, he would have made a less simplistic movie.
If Two Lovers winds up being Phoenix's last movie, at least it offers posterity incontrovertible proof that, once, he was a contender.

It's a thin premise, and I Love You, Man features the usual quota of jokes involving masturbation, projectile vomiting and flatulence. But is it worth it? Thanks to Rudd and Segel (and some terrific cameos), totes magotes.

For all its vivid evocation of its characters' tomorrow-we-die bonhomie, the film finally never quite convinces viewers of its central subject: the sisterly, almost sapphic bond between Vera and Caitlin.

The super-duper-3-D-big-screen-Imax-deluxe extravaganza that is Monsters vs. Aliens has bells and whistles, superb technical sophistication and dazzling visual effects, sound, fury and Reese Witherspoon. What it doesn't have is heart.
Sort of a Before Sunrise for the sunset years, this quiet romantic comedy takes a cinematic chestnut and somehow infuses it with a sense of rue and regret that makes it seem new.
Even though it's pretentious and overlong, A Christmas Tale is still maddeningly engaging, thanks in large part to its attractive and gifted cast.
movie_title: Un Conte de Noël (A Christmas Tale) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The Quantum of Solace filmmakers have produced a super-serious, often visually incoherent travelogue of revenge and trumped-up angst.

Like all good fairy tales, this outsize celebration of perseverance and moral triumph contains within it a deeper idea -- in this case, the relative nature of what we think we know, and what's worth knowing at all.

One of the great strengths of CSNY is how skillfully it deflects criticism of 'four balding hippie millionaires' taking to the stage to criticize American politics; the film is peppered with excerpts from some of the tour's earliest and nastiest critics.

With delectable-looking home movies of the couple's travels in California and Europe, Chris and Don offers an intimate portrayal of a passionate, enduring association, as well as a social history of postwar life.

This by turns inspired, goofy and finally weirdly hyper-violent celebration of male bonding and chronic Peter Panism joins such classics as Up in Smoke and the Harold & Kumar oeuvre in its sunny, raunchy acceptance of its own idiocy.
Baghead is at its best when it captures the subtleties of romantic machinations, macho power plays and the indignity of women aging in Hollywood.
What Stealing America lacks in formal elegance it makes up for in important information that deserves far more compelling delivery, as does its call for a return to paper ballots.
Made with uncommon skill and assurance, the film never succumbs to rank sentimentality, but it manages to get at the nuances of human relationships.
An extravagant, visually stunning feast of sensory delights, Jiri Menzel's winsome comedy, set in World War II-era Prague, pirouettes along a beguiling but treacherous line between horror and whimsy.
movie_title: I Served the King of England (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The best part of the movie is watching Gervais and Leoni delight in each other in scenes that burst with spontaneity and genuine warmth.
Overwrought, overproduced, overbusy and overlong, Miracle at St. Anna finally suffers from the worst filmmaking sin of all: the failure of trust, in the story and the audience.
As depressing as it is to find so many gifted artists reduced to making a talking-dog picture, Beverly Hills Chihuahua turns out to be genuinely sweet.
Nick & Norah possesses an inescapable, winsome appeal. It's an alt.romance, dedicated to the B-side of love.
Body of Lies clicks along at an engaging pace, legibly limning its multitude of characters and even throwing in a good bit of wry humor.
The Express finesses a cinematic hat trick: It's entertaining, deeply moving and genuinely important.
The Pool takes viewers on a journey to Goa that is startling not only in the lush physical beauty it reveals but also in the subtle, finely wrought emotions it stirs.
W. is a scattershot attempt at stylized portraiture that plays like a half-baked editorial cartoon.
Sometimes silly, often scathingly funny, What Just Happened? finally possesses a winning mix of toughness and heart.
The British actress Sally Hawkins delivers a nervy, utterly captivating tour de force performance in Happy-Go-Lucky, Mike Leigh's transporting new film.
Despite its own synthetic, over-processed production values, "High School Musical 3" exudes genuine appeal, thanks to director Kenny Ortega's brilliant choreography and a gifted cast.
Pride and Glory would be risible if it weren't so reprehensible.
The Unknown Woman falters when it falls into exploitation and fatal contrivance.
Fans of the first Madagascar will find much to enjoy in Escape 2 Africa.
Journey to the Center of the Earth is terrific family entertainment, an action comedy on a par with Night at the Museum and National Treasure.
movie_title: Journey to the Center of the Earth (2008)

movie_review_blurb: In going to such great lengths to correct the racists, bigots and haters of the world, Levin gives them way too much credit.

Because it gets so close to the real thing, the film does a good job of letting even the most hopelessly landlocked viewers experience vicariously the unique allure and adrenaline rush of being one with a surging 60-foot wall of water.
This smart, good-looking movie deserves an audience.
A film that even with its flaws should be cheered for preserving the later years of these towering musical talents.
Forgettable, if good-hearted, movie.
A gentle, surprising little movie whose rewards lie in what its characters don't say as much as in what they do.
Its laughs are sweet-natured, and Heaven knows the lead players earn every one.
It's an exhilarating, funny, very sweet movie.
True to his temperament, Kaurismaki has made another funny-sad movie about the tenuousness of life, in all its ambiguity and nonsensical symmetry.

Finding Nemo will engross kids with its absorbing story, brightly drawn characters and lively action, and grown-ups will be equally entertained by the film's subtle humor and the sophistication of its visuals.
Does ample justice to the complexity, even profundity, of a creative collaboration that has brought deep joy and meaning to generations of fans throughout a career that just entered its third decade.
Just might be the most action-packed suspense thriller of the summer.
A spectacle of suffering and liberal guilt.
Dworkin gives a compassionate face to the miasma of New York's family court-social services matrix.
A candid, colorful and deeply meaningful sociocultural time capsule.
Jarecki has created a tour de force of narrative ambiguity, and in doing so has made one of the most honest reality shows ever.
To call it sophomoric would libel even the most pathetic, pimply underclassman.
movie_title: Dumb and Dumberer: When Harry Met Lloyd (2003)

movie_review_blurb: A belabored, ostentatious, overlong behemoth.
Godard has created such a hermetic, uncompromising world that only the hardiest cinematic spelunkers are likely to appreciate its depths.
movie_title: In Praise Of Love (Éloge de l'amour) (2002)

movie_review_blurb: An essentially derivative, static and zing-free endeavor.
A thoughtful, vivid spiritual coming-of-age story that transcends its particular cultural context.
Detestable, not just because its action is so vile or its technique so crude, but because its moral imagination is so impoverished.
A nearly two-hour exercise in chaotic action and coarse, annoyingly coy sexuality.
The filmmakers have taken a bet that an unsexy, unpretty and unconventional movie about bank robbery and gambling can be as captivating as its flashier mainstream counterparts, and they've won.
Seems every much as finely calibrated as In the Company of Men.
Very soon it's clear that even from a camera trained on the front seat of a car, an amazingly full and complex portrait of Iranian life can emerge.
An impressively authentic portrait of teenagers who, given too much money and freedom by absent parents, have confused maturity with a veneer of sophistication and blase amorality.
It's a warm, if pallid, romantic comedy that may not do much more to burnish Lopez's reputation, but will certainly not bruise it.
A tepid romantic comedy that strains not only credulity but patience.
Outstanding entertainment for little ones but just as rewarding for their adult companions.
From any other filmmaker, Evelyn would be merely a forgettable good intention, but when you consider that Beresford is the man who brought us Black Robe and Breaker Morant, it approaches heartbreak.
A movie of technical skill and rare depth of intellect and feeling.
Searing dramatization of a story of remarkable courage, stamina and spirit.
The cinematic equivalent of a glass of warm milk to soothe overstimulated nerves.
A veritable orgy of strained physical gags, inane vulgarity and poor comic timing.
Lee has created that rarity in filmmaking: a movie we need, right now.
A by-the-numbers sop to adolescent testosterone overload.
[Tries] desperately to lower the bar for scatological gags, rank sexual humor and cheap physical shots.

The effect isn't just frenetic, unfunny and dull. It's kind of creepy.
A thoroughly absorbing and deeply affecting portrait of an extraordinary leader.
A movie that sags and drags under the weight of poor pacing, execrable writing and largely unlikable characters, including a leading man viewers can never really warm up to.
A soul-deadening experience.
A nasty, formulaic and unforgivably obvious procedural.
A gorgeous and surprisingly profound meditation on a place and its people.
Doesn't begin to live up to the giddy energy, romance and terrific dancing of its progenitor.
A surprising, ingenious film.
A movie that, in the story of one man dying, shows us all how to live.

Martin and Hunt give the production a mellow warmth. And Levy has cast an appealingly diverse bunch of kids to play the young Bakers.

movie_review_blurb: An endless, virtually laugh-free pastiche of Aaron Sorkin by way of Aaron Spelling.
Webber makes a confident if torpid debut here.
The loudest, trashiest, stupidest, cheesiest celebration of ritualized male aggression of 2004.
Firmly ensconced among the forgettables in Stiller's career.

One more case study in how loads of taste, talent and accumulated filmmaking wisdom don't guarantee success.
The movie brings the audience back to 1980 with bone-crunching verisimilitude.
The movie isn't only boring; it's troubling.

As visually accomplished as Tokyo Godfathers is, the story is the most primitive form of drama, one that counts on improbable coincidence to propel the story to its sudden, implausibly symbolic conclusion.

A movie marred by a flaccid script, listless pacing, a plethora of cutesy-poo gags and Ray Romano.
A boilerplate melodrama whose good guys and bad guys are so baldly drawn they could have been conceived by Friz Freleng.

May have succeeded in exploiting Jesus's death for its most highly pitched emotion and drama. But in the process, for many believers, it may have served only to trivialize and further obscure the story's most central and sacred mysteries.
A welcome fix to audiences for whom today's Jumble game just isn't enough.
Nearly all are almost painfully self-conscious as the actors strain for the hip brand of improvised spontaneity that is usually guaranteed by a Jarmusch production.

Leconte has made a film every bit as elegant, tactful and carefully composed as William himself.
An often grave but sometimes hilarious picture of a hugely powerful network.

movie_review_blurb: A taut, riveting, uncommonly well-made film.
Deserves credit, not only for choosing a wonderful and deserving subject for a film, but for doing him proud.

movie_review_blurb: The film may be maddeningly obtuse, but its images are dazzling.
If Kelly felt it necessary to add the new material, that's all to the good. It just means there's more to love.
Smart, engaging discourse.
Might qualify as the most misguided, ill-conceived and lamentable film of [Lee's] career.
A movie in which an extraordinary collective act of moral and physical courage is relegated to a backdrop for a mushy, synthetic family melodrama.
A grisly, depraved and wholly uninvolving exercise in empty mannerism.
That rare movie that manages to be not only an adroit, carefully observed study in character and suspense, but important.

Even without deep knowledge of Thai politics and history, fans of war pictures will be impressed by Jitnukul's achievement in creating a detailed and graphic, if overheated, account of this ultimate underdog story.
A delirious piece of pop ephemera, a time capsule set on the cusp between the Summer of Love and the Day the Music Died.

The best thing about all of this is Bettany.
It gets on the cinematic record that the Ramones were here, and that they mattered.

Shockingly inert.
A gripping, deeply moving film.
An adaptation of another Cunningham book that, like The Hours, comes with its own set of challenges, which director Michael Mayer handles forthrightly, with precise emotional pitch.

Bears the unmistakable stamp of authenticity, even at its most outrageous.
Still holds up beautifully, as both pointed satire and silly, stakes-free comedy.
This is one long sit, made all the more so by a turgid story, a dour visual palette and uninspiring action.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A lively, absorbing, often uncannily authentic docudrama.

The Chronicles of Riddick doesn't hark back merely to the classic horror or science fiction canon but to nearly every single cinematic genre in the book, from westerns to film noir to sword-and-sandal epics.
Bland, workmanlike and instantly forgettable.
Cinema at its most intellectually honest and morally necessary.
movie_title: S21: The Khmer Rouge Death Machine (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Modestly amusing teen summer comedy.

Transcends genre to become a deeply affecting allegory about the importance of patience and acceptance.

movie_review_blurb: The best thing about Fahrenheit 9/11 is that viewers can disagree with the filmmaker's own assessment that the war was fought for money and power but still emerge with some healthy questions of their own.
This is a movie that isn't ashamed to wring each teardrop by any means necessary.

Harbors some indelibly arresting images and characters whose stories, even at their most superficial, manage to be authentically inspiring.

A carefully conceived, thoughtfully orchestrated effort in taste and restraint that ultimately is too restrained and tasteful.
Succeed on its own terms as an entertaining mid-season popcorn movie.
An exhilarating, often mind-blowing history of surfing.

Has the cozy, genteel warmth of a well-worn blanket.
Absorbing, funny, exhilaratingly entertaining.
A thoroughly unnecessary but nonetheless satisfying adaptation of the cheeseball 1980s TV series.
Begins as a promising meditation on one of America's most durable obsessions but winds up as a slender cinematic stunt.
From each obvious setup to its hoary payoff, Grown Ups hews faithfully to its formula...

"The Wrecking Crew" succeeds as important cultural history. But it's also deeply personal for Tedesco ...
The dubious merit of tiresome "don't drop the soap" jokes aside, "Get Hard" sometimes veers perilously close to committing the very sins it aspires to criticize.

There are just as many breathtaking moments to be found in the film as there are in the work it's about.
Even at its most confected, this is a film that tells the truth.
A tasteful, mildly intriguing romantic drama from writer-director Benoît Jacquot.

As he did in the first "Avengers," writer-director Joss Whedon avoids the fatal trap of comic-book self-seriousness, leavening a baggy, busy, overpopulated story with zippy one-liners, quippy asides and an overarching tone of jaunty good fun.

A fascinating discovery from a filmmaker whose sensitivity to the most confounding motivations is equalled only by his compassion for those who succumb to them.

There isn't one joke, sight gag or piece of slapstick tomfoolery that lands with any success or originality ...
"Iris" serves as a spirited, often dazzling primer in how to fight the dying of the light and feel fabulous while doing it.
Clinical, exacting, superbly intuitive, Saint Laurent and his associates put painstaking effort into everything from the tension of a seam to the width of a lapel.
At times, "Unfriended" really clicks - but ultimately, it's a drag.

Sure, it's pat and occasionally patronizing and too adorable by half, but it's also a rare, optimistic portrait of aging that suggests it can be a productive, erotically charged time of life.

movie_review_blurb: "Selma" invites viewers to heed its story, meditate on its implications and allow those images once again to change our hearts and minds.
If you aren't moved by Life Itself, you ought to have your heart examined.

Beneath those puppet-headed antics, and true to its title, Frank is improbably, disarmingly honest.
Cockamamie, kaleidoscopic, languidly compelling ...

"A Most Violent Year" is an engrossing, often beautiful film, and a breakout opportunity for Isaac, whose similarly self-contained performance as a sadly self-aware folk singer in "Inside Llewyn Davis" was unfortunately overlooked last year.
There's no doubt that Aniston deserves more roles like this one but, with luck, in less maudlin, more surprising movies.

What might have been a frank portrayal of high school culture and challenges ends up veering between being either too cynically hyper-sexual or preachy.
A tightly coiled rage seethes beneath the pretty surface of American Beauty, a wickedly funny black comedy directed by newcomer Sam Mendes.
There's much to be said for a film that doesn't overreach, delivers on most of its promises and gets the audience out the door in just over an hour and a half.
"Girlhood" is a mesmerizing exercise in the enlightenment that can happen when a filmmaker shifts the male cinematic gaze ever so slightly and uncovers what looks like a whole new world.

movie_title: The 100-Year-Old Man Who Climbed Out the Window and Disappeared (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Despite his own failings and faults, Leigh and Spall's Turner is a man consumed by the search for truth and beauty, even in the midst of the less than pretty truths of his times.

It's a crowd-pleaser every bit as calculated and earnestly defanged as a Golden Oldies bus-and-truck tour. It's fun while it lasts, even if the Bic lighters stay safely pocketed at the end of the show.

As enlightening as it is entertaining, as sobering as it is exhilarating, "Straight Outta Compton" reminds viewers not only who N.W.A. were and what they meant, but also why they mattered - and still do.
Heller and Powley present a journey that, stripped to its most basic emotional elements, is timeless and universal.
movie_title: The Diary Of A Teenage Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: "We Come as Friends" has been beautifully filmed, with Sauper's God's-eye views of his plane's wing and the African landscape below resembling something Saint-Exupéry might have conjured.

"Learning to Drive" would be an entirely inert expedition were it not for Clarkson, who plays against Kingsley's sentinel of propriety with her signature radiance and birdlike gracefulness.

What "Black Mass" gains in moral honesty, it loses in dramatic momentum. Even filmmakers and actors as fine as these haven't managed to solve one of cinema's most enduring challenges - making criminals interesting without exalting them.
A thoughtful, moving testament to genuine connection.

If "The Black Panthers" has been designed to leave viewers outraged and energized in equal measure, it succeeds with admirable style. It counts both as essential history and a primer in making sense of how we live now.
movie_title: The Black Panthers: Vanguard Of The Revolution (2015)

movie_review_blurb: "The Intern" feels a little bit like the tai chi exercises that Ben does in the park throughout the film - you look for something to react to and laugh at and maybe even shed a tear about, but you wind up pushing against a puff of air.

"Mississippi Grind" winds up being an improbably satisfying, even heartwarming character study.

The problem-solving valorized in "The Martian" provides a simultaneously stirring and spirited example of how cool science can be. As NASA-Hollywood plots go, this one is worth lapping up like all the water on Mars.
The drama that "Freeheld" unsuccessfully strives for ultimately can't compete with the far-more-compelling facts that inspired it.
