movie_review_blurb: Though it's interesting to be given such a blank slate, 35 Shots Of Rum can try the patience. By denying us background detail, Denis makes it hard for us to get involved with the characters.
Excruciating, OTT, hilarious.
Undemanding, observant and beautifully performed, this is Richard Curtis-lite with added reassurance: no challenging questions here.
An entertaining watch for thriller fans wanting more than ticking bombs and terrorists.
There's nothing much to this sweet transatlantic romance but Hoffman and Thompson are a pleasure to watch throughout.
A few in-jokes will amuse Terminator fans but this is best viewed as an entertaining add-on to the franchise rather than a promising reboot.
There's the potential for 'Superbad'-style comedy when Denis and his pal go on the run with Beth and friends, but the pace is slow and lines fall flat thanks to long pauses and hammy delivery.

Don't expect realism from this frothy little number, but do expect a bit of heart-warming cheer courtesy of romantic unions, overcome prejudices, reconciled enemies and general peace and understanding.
Despite the fact that this is a beautifully-shot, dryly funny period drama, some audiences might prefer to stick to the sheer escapism of Austen's fictional work, which follows a similar formula.
A flat story, lean characters and a miscast lead make this a poor facsimile of period epics like Farewell My Concubine.
Kiddie-friendly toilet humour, a whiff of suspense and familiar voice actors make it passably entertaining, but there's little warmth or emotional satisfaction to be had from its cynical characters.
Sharp dialogue and detailed observations make it a good deal funnier than you might expect.
As a glimpse into a curious subculture this provokes interest, but in dramatic and political terms it's a missed opportunity.
Occasional funny moments but this is very very thin.
...Pleasing but ultimately unsatisfying.
None of the leads convince or engage, and supporting characters are either gay stereotypes, routine little sisters or functional best friends.
Not the worst of its kind, but few over the age of 14 will find it worth forking out for.
If Lawrence makes you laugh, you'd be better off watching him do stand-up.
A wistful smalltown drama, this is predictable and pleasant, with enjoyable performances. It suffers from heavy-handed symbolism, but as an undemanding mainstream movie it has its simple pleasures.
...There's no artful black comedy here, just an uncomfortable clash between broad provincial humour and a murder plotline.
...Opting for a broad, light mood that's at complete odds with the darker potential of its political premise.
Another pointless remake with a cast who should know better.
Add to this a confused moral message and it's clear that, as its title inadvertently suggests, this romantic comedy never gets off the ground.
It's good old-fashioned family entertainment.
The Lake House demands a serious suspension of disbelief, but if you accept it as a romantic bit of nonsense, it has its pleasures.
The plot, needless to say, is negligible.
There's charm in this simple underdog tale, but clunky plotting and characterisation mean it has 'telemovie' written all over it. You'd be better off renting Spellbound instead.
A breezy, passably funny spin on a children's classic, mixing slapstick and farce with character humour and delighting in demolishing stereotypes.
A likeable cast is underused in this cut-price guy comedy with only the occasional laugh.
As limp as it is lazy.
A leisurely feelgood rom-com.
Amy is little more than a pretty face, undermining the film's female appeal and leading one to wonder if Dukes of Hazzard eye candy Simpson is becoming a trifle typecast.
A slow-burning examination of disability and grief is enlivened by a top-notch cast and a gently witty script.
Ferrell's man-child invites sympathy and sniggers, making this amusing despite some flimsy plotting. Sight gags and a Santa-centred story should keep the kids happy, too.
The film is so jubilantly over the top and aware of its own failings, it's hard not to laugh.
A light, uneven Pygmalion story that may win young girls over with its wish fulfilment theme and teen movie staples, but does not live up to the expectations created by the cast and director.
A gleefully subversive but over-simplistic rude little indie that's starting to gain cult status.
By and large this is a hollow, laugh-free zone paying lip service to the issue in trite, predictable fashion.
A slow-burning but enticing thriller, it captures its working class Glaswegian setting in absorbing detail.
While Tatum has rough charm, Dewan is more dancer than actress.
More successful as a documentary than a drama, this offers a gently absorbing glimpse into nomadic Mongolian life.
movie_title: The Cave of the Yellow Dog (Die Hohle des gelben Hundes) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Star Missy Peregrym shows more promise in her first feature, despite the fact that her teenage years are clearly behind her, and her charismatic screen presence enlivens an otherwise dull film.
It's the usual case of great dancing, bad acting and even worse dialogue in this very guilty pleasure for fans of the genre.
Takes a joke and runs with it -- sometimes too far, but usually long enough to wear you down and force you to submit to its craziness.
movie_title: Anchorman - The Legend Of Ron Burgundy (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Unfortunately, the performances are often clunky and the art direction and CG are wanting, so anyone over the age of eight is likely to find it cheap around the edges. One for very little mermaids.
This fantasy comedy should entertain its pre-teen female market -- and repel those silly superficial boys (swoon).
A highly engaging attempt at Shakespeare's most domestic tragedy.
There's much to provoke thought about the motivations of these self-destructive terrorists.
Fails on both an emotional and comedic level.
The road doc format's nothing new, but it preserves such a brief, precious moment in rock history that it'll have fans captivated.
This is simple, lazy storytelling rendered merely functional by appealing leads and the eternal lure of romantic fantasy.
This attempt at a modern-day Cinderella story is about as PC as a Career Girl Barbie and disappoints due to poor structure, flimsy characterisation and insufficient wit to distract from the above.
Inane banter soon takes over and is not helped by an unlikely, flashback-heavy subplot about Eddie (Cedric the Entertainer) and a lost love.
The movie may dole out a few guilty pleasures, but you won't believe a word of it.
An uncomplicated, nicely shot tale that ticks all the right boxes for those after a good old-fashioned weepy.
A good-natured but self-indulgent camp comedy lacking in originality, character and comic timing.
There's atmosphere and absurd wit, but the surreal style creates a distance from the characters that's only likely to be appreciated by fans of Maddin's self-conscious artistry.
movie_title: The Saddest Music in the World (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The rags-to-riches plot should keep hopeless romantics happy, but you just can't help wondering what Hugh Grant, Sandra Bullock and a team of decent joke writers might have achieved with this one.
This is the kind of romantic comedy you wish you saw more often.
Not as good as the original, but as far as sequels go, it's way, way above average.
Both the well-choreographed crash scenes and the gritty cinematography hint at a better film. Shame no-one took the time to make it.
The film's easy charm, infectious soundtrack and tidy choreography should still win over new fans as well as old.
An unpersuasive moral journey, with a smattering of laughs, that fails to justify the insulting premise that only a man can help the ladies win at both basketball and love.
A pleasantly predictable film which ultimately demonstrates rather less ambition than its protagonist.
Watch (sober) at your peril.
Magic and realism just don't belong together here.
While their transformation is predictable, it's quietly enjoyable, and the teen angle opens the door to romance and gritty gang-war subplots.
The high school hijinks may entertain the young, but those more familiar with the Bard will recognise this as a wasted opportunity.
Cute, comical kids help make this ballroom dancing comp-romp a feelgood winner despite inexpert editing.
[A] comedy so broad it barely dents its targets and a patronising moral conclusion that goes against everything its protagonists originally stood for.
Money can buy you happiness in this inferior remake - although its makeover storyline may please fans of The Princess Diaries et al.
Thanks to a relatively gritty setting and an estimable adult cast, this sentimental story is rendered bearable for adults and children alike.
Despite a likeable cast and bursts of wit, this fails to work its darker comic themes into its picture of flawed-but-loveable rural Britain.
A subtle, slow-burning mystery that does justice to its themes of identity, sanity and sacrifice.
While a little too deliberate and reliant on its familiar formula, this still has its amusing, uplifting moments.

There's little tension or opportunity for emotional involvement in the brief story, and despite competent animation the cats are rarely anthropomorphised to good comic effect. One for anime -- and animal -- lovers only.
Man becomes mutt in this inoffensive, uneven comedy that fails to make the most of its comic potential or familiar cast.
This boastfully pushes the boundaries of taste, but lacks either wit or skill.
movie_title: The Sex Lives of the Potato Men (2004)

movie_review_blurb: This makes an even worse job of its premise than you might expect, leaving it to the usual sidekick, Cedric the Entertainer, to provide the occasional laugh as a convict-turned-holy man.
An offbeat, quietly absorbing film that manages to depict loneliness without being depressing. It's light on emotional impact, though.
A watchable, workaday rom-com with business as usual from the leads, a bland plot and inconsistent characters.
A routine romcom.
A straightforward revenge drama with added gore.
Smart casting and stand-out performances don't compensate for the twee source play and an over-ambitious screenplay from Branagh.
The closing message claims to promote tolerance, but this remains a lads' comedy: it's all about sniggering at pansies and peeking up girls' skirts. And even that market deserves something funnier.
movie_title: I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry (2007)

movie_review_blurb: In the hands of Mike Leigh, this could be a masterpiece, as it is, it's forgettable fun.
There's plenty of fun to be had with Death Proof, but its imitation of a defunct, low-budget style of movie-making is perhaps too accurate when it comes to the genre's flaws.
While diverting in parts, this struggles to make a convoluted plot engaging. We're still loving Romola Garai and Bryce Dallas Howard, though.
A visually stunning musical.
Don't come here looking for laughs: the conclusion is sobering stuff.
Things certainly go bump in the night in this slow-burning Stephen King adaptation. But 1408's short story origins are very clear: think a long, if enjoyable, episode of The Twilight Zone.
An atmospheric, slow-burning chiller that rewards the patient viewer with just enough jumps and bumps.
Self-consciously quirky but hard to dislike, with laugh-out-loud moments and a refreshingly unappealing hero.
Attempting to encompass too many genres dulls the overall effect but this still commands a certain fascination.
Robin Williams is merely annoying in this comedy with a few lively laughs, but a nonsensical and uninvolving plot.
As a portrait of our consumer-obsessed society through the eyes of an alienated teen, you'll buy into this from the first frame.
It may not set the box office on fire, but this canine caper is more agreeable than your average underdog tale.
An appealing little British comedy with a fun concept, a witty script and an uplifting ending. Bob Hoskins is a real stand-out: if only the film's hero had his sparkle.
The sunny setting, attractive leads and reasonably involving story help make The Heartbreak Kid a watchable frippery.
Anand Tucker brings Blake Morrison's autobiographical bestseller to the screen with sensitivity, humour and visual flair.
movie_title: When Did You Last See Your Father? (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Gripping and desperately moving.
The daily grind of a Brick Lane Bangladeshi is credibly brought to life in this sensitive and intelligent adaptation of Monica Ali's novel.
Just fine in a sentimental, mainstream kind of way. Although by constantly referencing Austen's sharp wit and characterisation, this can only ever come up short in comparison.

The script is so reliant on wish-fulfillment it forgets to add those important little touches: you know, wit, sincerity, characterisation, that kind of thing... A very cheap shot - and hardly anyone calls him 'Chuck'.
Political comedy morphs into attempted thriller in this confused, fitfully entertaining film.
Charming performances make this an easy watch.
The idea is intriguing, and the performances excellent, although lead Gordon-Levitt (Brick) is for once outshone by his co-stars.
This update on the Nancy Drew saga uses old-fashioned stylings in a modern context to confusing, and none-too-suspenseful effect. It's a non-event that fails to do the much-loved character justice.
Princess is rarely a dull watch, but it doesn't pack enough of an emotional punch.
Paper-thin characters, stilted conversations and abrupt editing mean this is hard to get involved with, and its link with Arthurian legend feels contrived and clichéd.
Swinging from mildly irritating to rather enjoyable, the film eventually settles at merely watchable.
This attempt at reimagining the Arthurian legend fails to raise the pulse due to some leaden dialogue and unconvincing performances.
While it's rarely fall-down hilarious, it's witty enough to please horror fans in search of a light-hearted tribute to splatter flicks of old.
The conclusion is desperately trite, but Linney's performance helps this comedy - based on a novel by two nannies, take note - feel like a credible peek behind very expensive curtains.
The age-old mystery doesn't exactly thrill, but there's humour here and there and a swotty heroine that parents, at least, will approve of.
It's sentimental stuff, but amusing in places.
A sad story, but well told, with respect for its subject and an eye for the Shakespearian tragedy in the tale.
Student horror fans may find this worth a giggle, but it's not the nail-biting experience the trailers promise.
'Evan Almighty' misses so many tricks, it ultimately misses the mark.
Let's just hope the kids find burping raccoons and crumbling ceilings hilarious.
It's a sad state of affairs when the fit of Hilary Swank's casual slacks is more interesting than a plague of locusts.
There is entertainment to be had here, but it's mostly at the expense of the film's rambling, increasingly ridiculous plot.
This Indian immigrant family saga is a pleasant watch, but given the emotive source novel, it's surprisingly superficial.
Ropey bit-part actors - this cheerful exploitation of The Full Monty formula still entertains.
This is no Full Monty, but like the film-within-a-film, it's got enough creativity and enthusiasm to win young audiences over. And, of course, it's also rather rude.
Even if you go back decades, body fascism has rarely been so brazen, or so unfunny. Horrifying.
A witty, entertaining road trip comedy that doesn't shy away from ambiguity or discomfort.
Messy, patronising and tonally confused, this vanity project - timed to co-incide with Hilary Duff's perfume launch - quite frankly stinks.
Has its inspiring moments - especially given the true story - and some tense, dramatic scenes amid the speedy montages of confusing gang action.
It's the stuff of simple comedy, but as frat-flicks go it's a return to form for director Todd Phillips.
A bit like the 'Friends' episode in which Phoebe has to choose between two men, only with Diane Keaton, and fewer laughs.
while Dougray Scott is a viable romantic alternative, he's absent from too much of the film, leaving Alice to discover 'The Truth About Love' long after we all stopped caring.
A decent idea and cast are neglected in this ungainly Britcom with less of the com. A British actress might have been a better bet for this one.
A bog standard all-girls-together comedy with a decent cast and less impressive characters.
A well-meaning British comedy that fails to deliver the laughs - or the romance.
Any potential in Boorman's sinister parable is frittered away with awkward dialogue, shallow characters and failed attempts at comedy. A curiosity at best.
Anderson bares (almost) all in this flawed but fitfully fascinating thriller with a comical, if less compelling, turn from Danny Dyer.
A lightweight teen horror that only breaks from the formula when it comes to the less-than-terrifying predator.
The muddled plot and stilted dialogue irritate to the point where you're tempted to side with the villain.
'Nancy Drew' still has a televisual feel - more 'Murder, She Wrote' than junior 'Marple'.
Patience will be rewarded.
movie_title: Onna ga kaidan wo agaru toki (When a Woman Ascends the Stairs) (1963)

movie_review_blurb: Exposing almost as much small-mindedness as Borat did, this provides food for thought as well as some darned good ditties.
movie_title: Dixie Chicks - Shut Up and Sing (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Fails to get under the character's skin.
A far-from-rosy life story makes this lengthy biopic entertaining, but despite a strong lead performance it fails to get under Piaf's skin.
A gripping thriller, this deserves to cross over from the subtitled bracket into mainstream cinema.
movie_title: Ne le Dis à Personne (Tell No One) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The chauffeur love interest feels a little tagged-on, but this is still a worthwhile watch for those interested in the dark side of fashion.
Speaking out against the proposed identity card scheme, Taking Liberties is both a call to action and a warning against a future where the current restrictions escalate into a Big Brother society.
Much like its characters: decorative, entertaining and emotionally empty.

Saffron Burrows is a stand-out as a provocative actress (and very possibly her mischievous lookalike), but it's not enough to make the muddled plot engaging, or fit for comparison with Klimt's stunning work.
A guilty pleasure -- but only if you like your action outlandish, your continuity challenged and your guts and gore splattered all over the screen.
Toni Collette must have owed the director quite a favour.

While beautifully cast and acted, this focuses on its comic strengths to the detriment of the drama, creating an unbalanced tone and leading to self-conscious attempts at serious observation. A pleasant watch, but nowhere near as profound as it thinks it
It's just a shame that none of the laughs are intentional.
Light of touch but overlong, this is saved by a sparkling performance from Romain Duris.
Light and entertaining, if a little clunky at times.

Righteous Kill is not particularly good. With any other stars involved, this would be swept under the carpet like any other mediocre procedural. But even with the big guys on board, it's a giant let-down.
Streep is as enjoyable as ever, and if laughs count for anything, this is one of the better romantic comedies of the season.
Likeable leads and the odd good joke makes this romance an amiable time-passer.
An occasionally engaging but often hamfisted urban fable.
A little long and rambling but it'll cheer up anyone still recovering from The Cove.
Night Will Fall isn't simply a film about the war, it documents the power of emerging technologies to reveal and publicise war crimes - something that also feels acutely relevant today.
It may be entertaining, but Wish I Was Here is far less profound than it thinks it is.
While Thwaites has visual appeal, he struggles to give us the layered, conflicted hero this film needs. Without it, The Giver is little more than stylish but saccharine entertainment for teens.
Much of the dialogue and performances are stilted, but as a kitsch cult watch it has its charms.

While the dancing depicted is often beautiful, this is more about the boys' friendship: a nostalgic insight into the kind of intense relationship that can occupy a teenager's world, but be all but forgotten in a few years' time.
It all escalates into an arch, knowing throwback to 80s horror-thrillers that's muddled in parts but never less than entertaining: think a trashier version of last year's Stoker.
A decent watch for the genre, with suspense and a promising turn from rising star McIntosh.
This freshly 4K-ed masterpiece of German Expressionism deserves to be seen on the big screen. Track it down and be rewarded with possibly cinema's first ever twist ending.
movie_title: The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari (Das Cabinet des Dr. Caligari) (1920)

movie_review_blurb: This is chiefly about the spectacle and the gags, which aren't frequent or original enough to compete with the likes of Pixar.
An impassioned, fly-on-the-wall look at a serious social issue.
A fuzzy, buzzy Brit com about what it's like to be twentysomething.
While the plot is straightforward, characters are well-drawn, many defined by ironic delusions.
Sugary rather than toothsome, this perma-grinned musical wears thin pretty fast.
A preposterous romp with little for adults to enjoy beyond Wootton's manchild gurning. To say this is slightly better than Nativity 2 is damning with faint praise.
A '90s nostalgia fest with some interesting points to make.
Taking a non-judgemental approach, the makers gain access to sex parties and explore the attraction and the dangers in interviews with NHS counsellor David Stuart.
There's too much going on and too little character development for this to become a Christmas classic.
Melodramatic episodes sit oddly with the dark comedy. But it's still a giggle ...
Miss You Already feels like chick lit for the big screen: a frothy, contrived confection with careful doses of sexy, silly and sad. But those sad bits will get you in the end.
It's an atmospheric, thought-provoking, melodramatic debut from July Jung.
Late director Albert Maysles (Gimme Shelter) beautifully captures her personality and her passion for creativity.
A soapy but stirring romance with two committed leads.
All cast and crew do an impressive job in making this unlikely proposition such an engaging, thought-provoking and darkly funny watch.
Fans will eat this up, though others will wish it delved further into the dark side.
movie_title: Backstreet Boys: Show 'Em What You're Made Of (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Even with a starry cast, the stirring true story is this drama's standout feature.
Sterling performances lift the occasionally soapy storyline in this semi-successful adaptation.
Some winning performances but the astonishingly low budget and shaky script does make for distracting viewing at times.
Uplifting, heart-warming, hilarious... not necessarily words you'd expect to apply to a black and white silent French film. But The Artist is no ordinary movie.
Not just another gritty London crime drama, this is compelling and credible with a convincing star turn from Frederick Schmidt.
A highly enjoyable glance at Gotham's veteran haute couturists.
Heartfelt but lacking freshness.
A few observational gags deliver, but all the doll-humping and chicken-slaughtering will haunt you for days.
As Apocalypse Now and The Duellists prove, Conrad tales have been adapted into fine films down the years. This, though, isn't one of them.
Offers cheery, lightweight fun without taking itself too seriously.
While it's as tacky and obvious as Sin City itself, this comedy is watchable thanks to a lively pace and spirited turns from Kline and Steenburgen. An unabashed old-timers' fantasy.
A frank and fitfully funny look at female friendship
Pretty Cuban landscapes and the graceful Acosta are the highlights of this slight but winsome road trip romance.
Kids should be game for the ride, and the colourful characters offer humour and poignancy.
Visually stylised and filled with a sense of impending doom, 'Harrigan' feels more like post-apocalyptic sci-fi than a nostalgic cop saga.
A flowerier adaptation of the Scott Spencer romance than Zeffirelli's '80s version, it's tailor-made for the Nicholas Sparks crowd.
The Kids Are All Right writer Stuart Blumberg's first directorial effort is a frothy affair with typically strong turns from Ruffalo and Paltrow.
This film's masterstroke is showing everything from Duncan's point of view, without the traditional cloying narration.
1D in 3D: the closest thing to a Shine A Light for Directioners.
Linda's feelings are rarely revealed: that's left to the gloomy final act, which feels more like a guilt-inducing postscript than a genuine reveal.
[It] gets off to an entertaining, action-packed start ... But it's soon bogged down by an increasingly convoluted plot, an overindulgent running time and absurd dialogue.
movie_title: The Mortal Instruments: City of Bones (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The young Aprile is a standout in a moving, hard-hitting and surprising adaptation of the Henry James novel.
Ropier than a flax sandwich, this by-the-numbers Brit thriller has the numbers in all the wrong order.
Fairly routine brunette-fighting-for-survival stuff with a liberal dose of dark humour.
Audiences purely interested in the cars won't be disappointed - frankly they're sexier than the cast.
An original premise and earnest tone go a long way.
Good British sci-fis don't come along very often, so this stylish slice of a dystopian near-future should be welcomed by fans.
A cornball '80s jukebox movie with little of the unselfconscious charms of Mamma Mia!.
The Rover is one of those compellingly nasty visions of the future that has plenty to say about humanity -- whether we want to hear it or not.
Despite a few missteps this is a spirited, touching romance and Shailene Woodley's best performance yet. Divergent fans after a weepie need look no further.
Sandler's jocular, lowbrow goofing will leave many cold, whether he's goading his teenaged daughter or taking an ill-advised spin on an ostrich.
The Wedding Singer director Frank Coraci mines few laughs from the script but Sandler fans will find something to enjoy. They usually do.
Kid-friendly with some neat visuals.
Director Stacie Passion doesn't try to ape Buñuel's surrealist twist on ennui in Belle Du Jour, instead crafting an enthralling, modern tale in which intimacy is a goal rarely achieved.
Sensitive performances from a willing cast bring Zola's novel to life on the big screen.
It's a zippy, sometimes entertaining ride with a fun start.
There's a strong whiff of The First Wives Club and an even a sprinkling of Working Girl here - but instead of updating the genre, The Other Woman rehashes it.
The by-the-numbers plotting is a little clunky but there's fun to be had in the cast's easy chemistry.
While The Fold has something to say about loss and family relationships, it doesn't probe too deeply.
Six Feet Under scribe Jill Soloway offers a wry perspective on married life as Temple's stripper-with-a-heart is lobbed into this domestic yarn like a firecracker in an arms cache.
Performances are strong, the chemistry is palpable and romantic sorts will get something from the Stockholm syndrome story.

"Everybody knows that the sequel's never quite as good," sing our fluffy friends during the opening number of a film with much to live up to after 2011's terrific reboot, The Muppets. The joke proves self-fulfilling ...
A terse tale of men in crisis.
Ultimately, it's popcorn nihilism without the big laughs that helped distract from the casual approach to life and death in 'Red'.
[A] handsome, slow-burning thriller ...
A fizzy, funny, period dramedy with top-notch performances, Florence Foster Jenkins doesn't take many risks but it's a very entertaining experience.
If 'Teeth' and 'Raw' got your tail wagging, you'll lap this up.
Daphne is a wisecracking wit who may just resemble women you actually know. Imagine that.
Carell's cartoonish antics are funny enough, but the two women are the tale's real champions.
If you thought that the anal sex joke at the end of 'Kingsman: The Secret Service' was the funniest bit, you're in luck.
The final match is an absolute nail-biter, reminding tennis fans how electric this sport can be.
Mitch seems not just hot-headed but borderline racist, and neither trait is addressed in a satisfying way.
It's sincere, thought-provoking and gives you space to meditate on its message.
movie_title: Tawai: A voice from the forest (2017)

movie_review_blurb: 'The Long Kiss Goodnight', 'La Femme Nikita', 'Kill Bill'... this South Korean thriller owes a debt to many a great female-assassin thriller, and it's a fun ride for fans of the genre.
The documentary's format is a little repetitive but the content is interesting and, at times, inspiring.

Tipped for an Oscar nomination, Jehane Noujaim's kaleidoscopic documentary offers a gripping, behind-the-headlines account of Egypt's 2011 Tahrir Square uprising and the complexities of its aftermath.
It should appeal to fans of offbeat character-driven dramas - not to mention fans of Cera himself, who's embracing these morally ambiguous characters with gusto.
Despite its weighty themes, Stephen Frears' film is almost as much a comedy as a drama.
Not much happens but it has plenty to say.
It's overlong and a little muddled in the third act but still a thrilling, energetic watch.
A wee treasure.
The comedy's anarchic tone is refreshing but it leaves little room for heart. You'll laugh, but you might feel a bit hollow inside.
Fans of Pooh and co get enough to make this an informative nostalgia fix.
It's a Mills & Boon kind of set up, but Winslet in particular adds authenticity and gravitas.
A stylish, grown-up vampire sci-fi with, literally, plenty of guts.
Credit to Stéphane Brizé for an impressive piece of filmmaking with a refreshingly contemporary approach.

Haggard, painful, longing, poignant, confused, alarmed, amused, dejected, sinister... [Toby] Jones can be all these things without saying a word. You're with him all the way, trying to decode the mysteries of his life and psyche.
Salim Shaheen is known as 'the Ed Wood of Afghanistan', so this documentary is as eccentric as you might expect.

Based on Hillary Jordan's novel, Mudbound -- co-adapted on the page by Rees and Virgil Williams -- is emotive but unsentimental: Traversing it feels as authentically gunky as the muddy swamps in which it is set.
DCEU is floundering. It needs to find a bold new direction if it ever hopes to flap its wings, let alone compete with Marvel.
The dialogue's sometimes clunky, and allusions to the atrocities of war are glossed over. But if you're in the mood for a sexy, pacy period thriller, it does the job.
If it's all a little too crowded with characters, Branagh's pacy direction keeps the story zipping along.
It'll probably be most appealing to scientists looking for a good laugh.
It's breathtaking to watch, although its meditative possibilities are limited thanks to Redford's narration and an overbearing orchestral accompaniment.
A magic realist fable set in present-day Zambia that has plenty to say about gender and superstition.
Double Date is a fitfully amusing British comedy-horror.
It's openly theatrical, but if it feels like a film of a play, it's a play you really should see.
Part mystery, part visual experiment, 'Loving Vincent' is a reverent ode to the 19th century painter Vincent van Gogh.
More time could have been spent developing the bond between the men, but ultimately this is quite gripping: a weepie bromance. You don't see one of those every day.
It's by turns clunkily contrived then wondrously natural (if raw) - let's hope Gharavi, like her heroine, progresses towards greater fulfillment.
A challenging and frequently uncomfortable watch that messes with your sympathies.
Dan Stevens is the one genuinely likeable element to this dreary Downton-on-Sea.
The increasingly impressive Taylor-Johnson dominates the screen time.
The film's bouts of slapstick and sentiment sit slightly oddly with its downbeat tone, but Harrelson is consistently funny.
Sheridan, Cohen and Powley are a terrific trio in a stylish crime thriller that takes us on a trip through the seedy side of California and beyond.
Hard to root for but mesmerising to watch, Sloane is expertly portrayed by Chastain in this dialogue-heavy lobbyist thriller that should please fans of both actor and genre.
Vikander and Fassbender are riveting in a handsome period drama that begins beautifully, but becomes increasingly contrived as it tries to wring as much drama as possible from its set-up.
If the first 15 minutes of Up were set in London, animated by Raymond Briggs and stretched into a feature-length film, it might look a bit like this.
'The Hitman's Bodyguard' is not exactly killing it, but coasts on the charisma of its central stars.

The most memorable scenes come from True Blood's Sam Trammell as a warm, cultured family man who explains his racial hatred in a matter-of-fact manner: particularly chilling in the current political climate.
Cox will always be watchable, and goes for it here, but the film's makers seem not to know the potential of their own film.

Other films -- including David Fincher's The Game (1997) -- have done this better, but with its engaging story, energetic soundtrack and slick production values, Nerve is an easy watch for restless young minds.
Giant expectations may lead to tiny disappointments in this two-hander that's slow in parts. But it still offers magic and visual delights, and the final act is a treat.
Riseborough steals the show in a moody period drama loaded with atmosphere and tension.
An enjoyable, involving British drama with an impressive turn from newcomer Scott Chambers.
A sensitive, sensual and occasionally amusing portrait of teenaged obsession with a winning turn from Lawther.
A slick, stylish melodrama with an involving story and a cracking cast. Star Adriana Ugarte is a real find.
You'd have to be very young and naive not to see the twist coming, but perhaps that is the point.

The tone balances realism and optimism with the accent on the latter; ultimately Patti Cake$ has the kind of uplifting, defiant-misfit mood that's easy to compare with fellow Sundance hit Little Miss Sunshine.
An amusing watch, this has a freshness and naturalism rarely found in the typically over-styled French romcom genre
Portia is in many ways a typical [Tina] Fey character but the unfunny and clichéd script too often reminds us this is no 30 Rock.
It's a fun set-up with a terrific cast - [Jesse] Eisenberg plays against type as a smooth-talking card trickster while [Woody] Harrelson radiates easy charm as a mentalist and serial flirt.
[Susanne] Bier's intelligent direction, smart screenplay and canny casting make it a cut above your average middle-aged wish-fulfilment romance.
[Jack] Black is hilarious, all towering tolerance that finally reaches boiling point.

It's too superficial to maintain tension as a character-driven drama, and not funny enough to overcome an aimless plot and confused tone.
Antiviral is a none-too-subtle comment on tabloid-generated fandom. But it's undeniably intriguing and loaded with Cronenbergian atmosphere.
This doesn't zip along in the manner of typical Hollywood entertainment but it's memorable cinema with a finale that will stay with you long after viewing.
All in all, perfectly fine thanks to the cast and a fitfully witty script - but nothing to write home about.
Without passion, this slight story is of no interest.
movie_title: Confession of a Child of the Century (2012)

The story feels cobbled together and the dialogue is often painful.
Liman mines the story for familiar but fun comedy

Like her character, Bell has made herself a contender in a male-dominated industry. And a damn funny one at that.
Solid genre fare.

Confronting in its family drama, Beautiful Kate manages to simultaneously disturb and reward its audience with a strong, well rounded story and excellent performances.

Adam is about loving someone who's different, despite what your parents or friends may think. It's also unfortunately a won't-change-your-life cinema experience that, irrespective of its redeeming features, fails to satiate.
An absolutely rollicking adventure, Up combines incredible animation with funny, old fashioned storytelling.
The mental games that the characters play are underdeveloped, and the look of the film isn't worth leaving home for.
Right from the opening credits, with their strangely beautiful blown-up images of blood and the accompanying darkly rhythmic score, you're primed for something terrible to happen.
With poorly executed action, wooden acting and a dead script, this fantasy film is a strong contender for a Razzie.
While it tackles tough material, the terrific lead performances, stunning cinematography and uplifting score add up to a film that's pretty special.
While it's not without its flaws, this atmospheric and largely well-acted adaptation proves stronger than its source material.
While it doesn't hit the grand heights of other Pixar films, there's still a lot of fun to be had here.
While the animation is incredible, this also has heart and humour in spades, and proves just as engaging as its predecessor.

Red Dog is moving, uplifting and very funny. It has the potential to be a homegrown hit. And if it isn't, then there's something seriously amiss. It's the all-encompassing journey that movie trailers always promise to take you on.
With director Kevin Macdonald finding a rhythm among the myriad footage submitted, this honest, funny and touching doco is an incredible achievement.
Failing to succeed as a rom-com or a kids' flick, this feels surprisingly flat with the animals, and Kevin James, never really coming alive.
Despite strong performances and a rich premise, this is let down by its own self-importance and sentimentality.
movie_title: Snow Flower And The Secret Fan (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It's predictable kiddie fare and lags in the middle, but it's visually impressive, spirited and often fun.
It's a wonderful treat to revisit and the 3-D is beautifully utilised, but it's perhaps not the classic that Disney purports it to be.
Deftly steering between politics, poignancy and dark humour, this absorbing road movie is also one that proves morally interesting.
Working from an inspired original story, this beautifully executed adaptation is brilliantly acted and unexpectedly moving.
A good helping of amusingly sharp lines cannot save this uncomfortably odd beast.
movie_title: I Don't Know How She Does It (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Beautifully drawn and sidestepping cliché and forced sentiment, this sweet and inspiring Christmas story will bring out your inner kid.
A funny and touching monster mash-up, with wonderfully strong work from the entire cast...this is essential viewing for animation fans.
It's been a strong year for science fiction... And now Ender's Game comes along to make that resurgence look like the real thing.
Belly-laugh material it isn't, but Last Vegas fits the prescription for a happily undemanding piece of entertainment.
The direction from Steve McQueen is visceral, the script from John Ridley doesn't waste a word, and the performances are, without exception, brilliant.
It's out-of-this-world funny.
Lovely as it all is, it's not the classic Disney's pitching for. It's a nice one for littlies, but adults may find it more of a visual experience than an emotional one.
The script (co-written by debut feature director Sarah Smith) is fortified with meaning and smarts and plays well for both children and adults.
While the jokes are obvious, this fun family film has a big heart, an element missing from the recent slew of kids' movies about animals.
movie_title: Cats & Dogs: The Revenge of Kitty Galore (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Smart and tremendously entertaining but the clever premise soon loses steam.
A thrilling and utterly brilliant mind-twister, which finds the human story amidst the edge-of-your-seat action.
Displaying a visual flair rare for a family film, this is entertaining, escapist fun.
movie_title: Spy Kids: All the Time in the World in 4D (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Saldanha has proven himself with the Ice Age trio of films, and the animal characterisations here are just as strong. Rio is also visually superior. Full of colour, life and humour, it's a story about freedom and love -- and it soars.
How I Ended This Summer is over-long with too many empty stretches. It tests your endurance, yet this uncomfortable Arctic trip just still might be worth taking.
Driven by Ryan Reynolds magnificent performance, this tense and ambitious film is absolutely riveting to watch unfold.
While undeniably a chick flick, this is a classy one bolstered by an all-round excellent cast and well crafted script.
While there's insight to be gained, this overly long and often mundane doco is unlikely to spark an interest in the general viewer.
movie_title: La Danse -- Le Ballet de l'Opera de Paris (2009)

movie_review_blurb: There's a bold splash of the surreal in this inspired portrait of a man whose life really is too big for one film.
While it's let down by its disorienting camera work, this is informative, entertaining and impassioned.
It's about people -- specifically Harry, Hermione and Ron. If you've gone the distance with this franchise, you already care about them. But here, you'll care that much more.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Powerfully shot from within the tank, this unflinching war drama is unforgettable.
Leaves you feeling entertained -- if not entirely satisfied.
Despite the terrific voice cast and eye-catching animation, this seems disappointingly formulaic and fails to offer real laughs.
Delivered with authenticity and driven by superb, layered performances, this is a profound and powerful viewing experience.
Cinematically told and firmly rooted in its characters, this is an absolute crowd pleaser.
Loss is central to this story, but this isn't another Australian film that will be accused of being bleak. It's realistic yet hopeful, a little mystical and simply quite beautiful.
While campy and clichéd, this is a surprisingly enjoyable piece of escapism with Christina Aguilera delivering an impressive turn in the lead role.
While it's no crowd pleaser, this visually stunning thriller glides on Aronofsky's visceral direction and powerhouse performances from the entire cast.
While the performances are solid and there are a handful of truly suspenseful moments, this thriller fails to rise above the formula.
Stylistically striking and featuring a clutch of stunning performances from emerging local talent, this is a remarkable achievement sure to generate discussion.
Weighed down by a shallow premise, cringe-worthy gags and mixed performances, this ends up one big, boring disappointment.
Closer to a comedy for adults than a kids' flick, this ground-breaking and simply unmissable animation bursts with creativity, humour and clever references.
For the most part, this proves a flat and underwhelming affair which redeems itself with a solid ending and a strong ensemble cast.
While there are gaps left uncanvassed, this remains an absorbing exploration of a crucial issue which not only exposes problems, but offers answers.
Driven by terrific lead performances, this achingly beautiful work challenges audiences emotionally and intellectually.
E.B. is brought to life by Brand, the CGI is seamlessly worked into the live action, and Hop is briskly paced. It's entertaining enough but ultimately disposable.
Tangled is not only visually splendid, but it's one to get swept away in. This is animation of the highest order. CGI geeks -- miss it and weep.
It's frustrating to see these guys -- who are obviously pretty clever -- waste their talent on parodies of things they probably thought were funniest when they were high.
It has a satisfying handful of strong chuckles, wild characters and performances, and mildly harsh potshots at the fashion industry to keep you amused.
One of those throwaway, cliché-ridden TV-star-to-film vehicles built upon the most rickety of plots.
For all of Kelly's storytelling troubles, he has no problem with creating the film's gorgeously ominous atmosphere.
The One's script is just awful -- from premise to storyline to dialogue.
This film was made to get laughs from the slowest person in the audience -- just pure slapstick with lots of inane, inoffensive screaming and exaggerated facial expressions.
So beautifully watchable and enjoyable that you'll happily inhale its jazzy, madcap ether.
A headache-inducing, lame-ass ride down memory lane.
Lowbrow, vulgar, and certainly formulaic, it's also creative, absolutely hilarious, and ... knows better than to shoot over its audience's heads.
Everything about this complete tripe is ludicrous.
Honestly, I think I was sick of it after the second TV commercial, never mind the film itself.
Equal parts offensive and moronic.
Showing that maybe baby boy Singleton's done some growing up himself.
Loud, smash-and-crash monster movie fun at its finest.
Visually awe-inspiring and groundbreaking.
Pretty brave in the subjects it takes on, and does its best to avoid many teen movie conventions.
[P]eople watching on the weirdest plane of humanity.
The characters are repellant, and not even in an entertaining or over-the-top way.
Quote not available.
The Brothers has a lot to offer.

If I were a guy, and a gorgeous woman took me into her apartment, had passionate sex with me and supported my ass for a month, it'd change my life, too! Perhaps this is more romantic science fiction than anything.
A train wreck of bad lines and predictable plot twists.
Wastes the talents of a great cast.
A sweet but flawed wartime romance with enough gorgeous scenery and quaint villagers to choke a horse.
While the Resident Evil games may have set new standards for thrills, suspense, and gore for video games, the movie really only succeeds in the third of these.
One of those magical and rare films with a nearly perfect mixture of beautiful writing, glorious music, elegant cinematography, remarkable acting, dazzling art direction, and an engrossing story.
Short, simple, charming, and brilliant.
substandard, unprofessional filmmaking
If you want your wild and crazy Will Ferrell, look for him elsewhere. But if you just want a few laughs from a movie that you know everyone's going to enjoy, Ricky Bobby's definitely your man.
movie_title: Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby (2006)

movie_review_blurb: just captivating enough to take your mind off the incredibly un-PC stance that it takes on hardcore issues

a documentary that can be taken about as seriously as its nutty subjects.

engrossing and rather endearing

a balls-out revenge tale
like watching a very non-scary, screeching, interstellar cockfight

Nothing about Underworld is original

indulge in the delights of Snyder's wild, new, imaginary interpretation

The mum, played by Kelly Preston, tells Daphne, "Getting to know yourself is the answer." And we thought this was supposed to be good family fun.

'An intelligent and inspiring portrait of how one experience can change a person's life.'

movie_review_blurb: Inception is dark, thrilling and bold, and most importantly, it will reach well beyond your highest expectations and wildest dreams.

Guy Maddin has never tipped quite so far in the direction of autobiography as he has with My Winnipeg, and the effect is unexpectedly charming.

Yeah, Pixar movies are usually good, but this one's unimaginably great.

movie_title: When Did You Last See Your Father? (2008)

movie_title: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants 2 (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The movie-a big fat episode, essentially, with a noticeably constrained budget-is a satisfying thriller, with romantic and religious angst substituting for explosions and chase scenes.

movie_review_blurb: What [Brick Lane] lacks in ambition, it makes up in intimacy.

movie_title: In Search of a Midnight Kiss (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Man on Wire is 80 minutes of white-knuckled suspense followed by a surprisingly emotional climax.

Between the ugly digital photography, the repellent characters, and the free-floating misogyny, Elegy is an unpleasant film.

An almost unwatchable film.

Frownland is nothing like a conventional comedy.

[Children of Men] is terribly exciting.

movie_review_blurb: This smart, amiable documentary is about corn: how it's grown, subsidized, processed, and how it sneaks its way into virtually every food on grocery-store shelves.
Julian Schnabel's first film since Before Night Falls is a gorgeous, canny, and sensual adaptation of a most unlikely story.
movie_title: The Diving Bell and the Butterfly (2007)

4 Months, 3 Weeks, and 2 Days, which was unjustly denied an Academy Award nomination for best foreign-language film, is grueling and unsentimental. The excellent acting is what keeps it humane.
Come for the fleeting shots of camp counselors Carrie Brownstein and Beth Ditto, stay for the wicked banshee screams of 7-year-old Palace and her song about how much San Francisco sucks.

Almost certainly the best movie in SIFF 2008, Abdellatif Kechiche's follow-up to Games of Love & Chance burrows into a tight-knit Tunisian immigrant community in a small port town in the south of France.
