Increasingly, it's obvious that much of the Marvel universe works best when it goes big and silly: Thor: Ragnarok is about as big and silly as a Marvel movie is ever going to get.
... Good Time always leaves just enough room between the dramatics for the characters to reveal their humanity.

While the idea of a "creepy clown' is pretty much an oxymoron - just put a regular clown out there and the creeps will flow naturally - Skarsgård's performance gives Pennywise some much-needed shading between the jump scares.
It's not a classic telling of a classic tale, but it sure is pretty to look at.
[Robert] Pattinson is enthralling as a man who never quite adds up.
The results [are] haunting.
The big moments are effective, but like Nichols' earlier films, it's the quiet moments that linger; he's a director that excels when he digs down past genre thrills to unearth their buried humanity.
The food and sightseeing is fun, but the relationship is the core here.
This is Lyndal's story and West gives a searing performance as a young woman clutching at her last chance to try to make things right.
This is the closest thing to a straight-up Alien remake the series has seen yet.
Rather than a marked comedown then, this is more a continuation of the series' gentle skid towards more traditional action fare.
Visually impressive and with a solid central performance, it's the soul-deep melancholy that animated the original that this version lacks.
By the big final battle -- which goes from the Power Rangers kicking rock monsters all the way up to them kicking a giant gold monster -- it's hard not to feel this film has earned its cheese.
Everything is competent, but rarely impressive.
It's a brave way to structure a film, and the sentimental side gradually undercuts the laughs until all that's left is a vague warm feeling towards a character we'd flee from in real life.
In spite of the garbled story the characters get plenty of strong moments that play to their core appeal.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: [A] masterful, often devastating film.

With the story's result already known, much of the suspense comes from seeing the characters' slowly dawning realisation of just how big this story is; the matter-of-fact way the pieces of the puzzle come together.
The accrual of small details adds immeasurably to this film's nightmarish tone.

The story he's [Terry Gilliam] telling is kind of muddled, drags on a lot of the time, and has an ending that fails to pull it all together. It's definitely something worth considering, but still; this is a theorem that doesn't quite add up.
Stunning, reverential and awe-inspiring in the best way, Godzilla hammers home the insignificance of individuals in the face of such forces.
Being forced to engage with the material just to try and make sense of what we're seeing is part of what makes this so compelling.
The good news is, once Maleficent goes full evil Jolie really lets loose, sweeping through the film as a force of nature.
Talking about performances or anything else traditionally associated with film is beside the point here, because the entire story is just a laundry list of scenes meant to make the audience bawl.

Smarter and funnier about its central conceit that you might expect and with a pair of great performances, [its] only serious flaw is a final act that ditches all the science-fiction stuff for a murkily shot and relatively unimpressive conclusion.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Blended is awful. It's the kind of awful film where it's hard to resist the temptation to just list all the awful things that happen in it and pass that off as a review.
Presumably there's some kind of story going on here but director Michael Bay doesn't seem all that interested in it so why should you be? But more often things just happen because EXPLOSIONS!
Dawn of the Planet of the Apes is a thrilling, compelling action spectacle that won't make you feel stupid for watching it.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: If Guardians of the Galaxy is just the latest burger off the fast food conveyor belt, it's awfully hard to deny that it's an extremely tasty burger.
Every glance and line of dialogue pushes the scene forward, every scene pushes the story forward, and if your attention wanders, there's a good chance the ending will just pass you by.
This is slightly more of a disappointment than the previous instalments, largely because (Banderas aside) it never gives any of the cast anything to do.

[Sarah] Snook's performance makes this story more than just a collection of clockwork turns; her tenderness at the story's core makes Predestination into a real movie, and it in turn makes her a star.
From a guy in his 20s this kind of sappy feel-good pap seemed at least kind of appropriate... From the same guy ten years later it just feels false.

It's the easy chemistry between Tatum - who gets funnier the dumber he acts, and here he's playing a character who can't remember what a library is called - and Hill that makes sure this is never less than entertaining.
It's rare that a band made famous by controversy can stay relevant even a few years on. But more than two decades later, N.W.A.'s music still has the power to shock and startle.
It's one of those rare films that actually gets more fun to watch the longer it goes on.
Youth skilfully evokes the joy and melancholy of time as it passes, the yearning for new experience that drives us on even as our ability to seize it wanes.

The fun of The Force Awakens comes from visiting an old friend and finding that little has changed; the excitement is that great performances from all four new leads means it's a strong foundation for whatever comes next.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It's in the performances that this film equals the energy of the cycling scenes.
The strong chemistry between Brie and Sudeikis makes this feel more cohesive than it actually is, but without a consistent tone underlying the jokes, it's hard to know how to react.
If it turns out that this really is the last Fast & Furious film, it's a good note to go out on.
Woodley's performance is strong enough to carry everything else here: maybe being Divergent is just another word for star power.
But every single scene of this film features a man treating everyone around him like dirt while pissing their money up against a wall and acting like the world owes him a living.
The Birdman/ Batman thing is a cool hook that ties in well with the public perception of Keaton's career.
Every time the film cuts to Martin Freeman as Bilbo, the nominal central character now stuck on the sidelines with next to nothing to do, it's clear how wrong all this has gone.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It's a comedy without laughs, a satire that takes two hours to make a two minute point; if you're reading this online, it's already too late.
This is a movie best enjoyed on a scene-by-scene basis, because the overall story is really a bit of a mess.
It's awesome, watch it at your earliest possible opportunity.

Seventh Son often feels like the kind of film that would work better with even less plot... if they'd simply outlined the story as "we got to stop that witch" and then just rattled through the action sequences as quickly as possible.
In this abstract world, the cast's strong performances provide vital slivers of humanity.
It's silly but fun, with just enough wry dialogue to let the audience know it's in on the joke and plenty of high octane action to keep the heart pumping.
Annabelle is a cheap-looking spin-off that adds nothing of interest to The Conjuring and certainly isn't a good standalone story.
It's an agreeably insane plot, which is hilarious if you're high, but the problem is the premise doesn't even come close to sustaining a feature length story.
An utterly enjoyable and oddly affecting experience that's not only Shyamalan's best film in years but also a cracking thriller in its own right.
Thankfully the ending packs a surprising amount of punch and the stakes are raised for an emotional conclusion.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: There's lots of action, but little consequence. There are lots of characters, but not much heart. There are fewer physical threats and more computer-generated creatures. It's excess without reason and can often feel oddly unengaging.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: 300: Rise of an Empire is occasionally unintentionally funny. That said, it's also utterly mesmerising, visually gorgeous and totally compelling.

The good news is that Under The Skin does indeed break out of its own formula. The bad news is that it does so in a way that seems to delight in obfuscating its message, and is wilfully, gleefully impenetrable.
It also, naturally, has an unforgettable soundtrack and so, ultimately, can be mostly forgiven for lacking the danger and unapologetic truth of the album it's named for.
"Chappie, Blomkamp's third film, is a mess. However it's a fascinating, occasionally glorious one that feels, for better or worse, a grimier, more personal movie from the South African director."
It Follows is well worth a look and if you go in not expecting the second coming of horror, you'll likely have a good time with this unique, slowburn supernatural fable.
One of the smartest, slickest and most intriguing sci-fi thrillers in recent memory, with a standout performances from Isaac and Vikander and confident, minimalist direction from Garland.
The Poltergeist remake is dull and almost entirely devoid of scares.
It can be your mission, if you choose to accept it, but there are many superior options for your entertainment dollar.
Against all odds The Man From U.N.C.L.E. is surprisingly enjoyable.
Trashy and silly and occasionally unintentionally funny, it is nonetheless weirdly compelling.
Violent, fast-paced, frequently silly, occasionally hilarious and unapologetically Aussie, Wyrmwood is a cult film that hits far more than it misses.
Boasting a stellar cast, a robust story and consistently energetic direction, The Conjuring is a true old fashioned ghost story, and a damn fine one at that.
Drag Me To Hell is the most fun you'll have being scared for a long time. Nice to see you back, Sam.
After delivering a brilliant first half, its ambition seems to exceed its execution, but despite becoming muddled, it remains a visually stunning and wild cinematic ride.

There's a massive hole in the roof of Crimson Peak's slowly sinking mansion, and the characters never seems to notice it... If you, like them, can ignore the similarly-sized holes in the movie's plot, you'll likely have a good time.
Shaun Of The Dead is quite simply a film you should not miss. A deserved hit in the UK, this hopefully marks a return to form for British cinema.
Bad storytelling is bad storytelling, no matter how many explosions, robots and hot chicks you have on screen.

District 9 is a brave, intelligent and exciting film. Some of its story beats fall into the "unlikely" category, but the central idea, the design, and the acting are so strong that you'll likely go with it and have a damn good time doing so.
Not entirely unsuccessful remake of a '80s slasher flick, there are enough staples of the horror genre here to entertain and scare audiences.
A tired imitation of the first film in the series, the 3-D offers little to improve this vacuous and unnecessary sequel.
Yes, it's charming, well shot and funny, but there are no real scares to be found.
Dredd not only succeeds as a brilliantly accurate adaptation of the decades-old comic book character, it's also an absolutely blistering and exciting dystopian action movie.
If you know what's coming, it might just kill the effect. That said, going in blind will almost guarantee a genuinely chilling horror movie experience that should be seen at the cinema.
What SAW VII doesn't have: a decent plot, characters you care about and an ounce of credulity. This is so over-the-top and convoluted it's goofy.
Admittedly better than its predecessor, Michael Bay still hasn't learnt that impressive action sequences don't make up for woeful acting and no character development.
Final Destination 5 is moderately enjoyable splatter for those in an undemanding mood but never attains any real scares or resonant moments.
A disappointing effort for fans of the original, this fails to find the balance between paying homage to its predecessor and carving out its own story.
A somewhat return to form for director Kevin Smith, this flawed but strangely compelling indie flick is refreshingly unpredictable.
If you hated the first two or loathe found footage films in general this won't change your mind but PA3 is a solid, mostly entertaining supernatural thriller.
It's not a sequel that needed to be made, but thanks to the charm of its leads and a tone that harks back to the wit and humour of the original, it's a pretty enjoyable trip.

There's a difference between slow burn and no burn, and sadly Paranormal Activity 2 belongs in the latter camp. It simply isn't engaging or scary. The promise in the premise is never fulfilled and the ending is weak and poorly judged. What a pity.
Ghost Dimension falls well short of the mark.
Forgettable but well-executed, Paranormal Activity 4 gives you exactly what you'd expect and nothing more.
Scouts Guide proves profoundly unsatisfying, a mishmash of tones and gags that you've seen done better, elsewhere, many times before.
movie_title: Scouts Guide to the Zombie Apocalypse (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Genuinely enjoyable popcorn entertainment that's dumber than a sack of monkey trousers but fun nonetheless.
T2 Trainspotting is about the comedown and facing the consequences
Get Out is an effective, thought-provoking, slow-burn thriller
Alien: Covenant lays on the gore and ratchets up the shocks to eye-popping extremes.
A bright, exciting film that manages to meld the more epic "gods among us" DC-style with moments of levity and pathos.
It Comes At Night is a slow-burn family drama with thriller moments and a tone more in keeping with apocalyptic feel-bad flick, The Road.
Annabelle: Creation is the first Conjuring spin-off that actually feels worthy of its source material.
...an exercise in joyless frowning and desperately unconvincing drama.
Terminator 2: Judgement Day was a great film when it was released 26 years ago and remains a great film today.
...a big, ballsy, crowd-pleasing monster movie with wonderful characters, creative scares and a sense of style...
...manages to be sporadically engaging but is too bloated and unwieldy to hit the mark like its predecessor.
...the kind of film you'll forget even exists in five years so why not cut out the middleman and just forget it now?
Ultimately Happy Death Day isn't quite the film it could have been.
Despite containing elements of sequel, prequel and reboot, Jigsaw feels very much like business as usual.
...a sumptuous, elegant, exquisite creation of the finest quality, stitched together by a master of the craft.

This is a $70 million movie with A-list stars who really should have known better and fails to deliver much more than the odd bit of interesting monster design and frequently unintentionally hilarious dialogue.
The Dark Tower is a bad film, certainly, but even worse it's a profoundly ordinary one.
...you'd be better off staying home and doing literally anything else.
It's tense, edge-of-your-seat stuff... for a while.
It's bloody and noisy and super stylish...
Creed manages to rise above its well-worn premise and deliver a film that is at once stylish, engaging and ultimately moving.
...an effective and engaging mystery with some unexpected twists and turns...
It certainly won't be a film for everyone, but for those who can handle the brutality and nihilism, there's a lot to love about The Hateful Eight.
"Deadpool fans will be gratified to see their meta merc smirking, stabbing and snarking his way through his foes, stopping long enough to make a bunch of dick jokes, before it's back to the action."
Gods Of Egypt offers a frequently spectacular, light, and knowingly silly good time.
It's a pity that such an unexpectedly effective thriller is so profoundly undone by a tonally disparate denouement.
...has stellar moments of horror...
...an ordinary sequel...
...charms and surprises in equal measure.
Charm goes a long way, but in terms of the Coens' overall oeuvre, Hail, Caesar! is endearing but inessential viewing.
...consistently funny, occasionally clever and undoubtedly unmissable if you're a baked potato.
...a compelling and tense popcorn movie...
...a riveting, white-knuckle ride, and a cracking good time at the movies.
...a slight but clever little tech thriller...
...yet another technically competent, above average but oddly unambitious rehash of a story we've seen many times before.
...an engaging, albeit slight, adventure that toys with the absurdity of mortality.
...rather pedestrian...
...an exercise in pedestrian storytelling with minimal tension...
Braveheart has a gut-wrenching, bone-breaking, sword-thwacking verve.
Like many artists today, Grisham and Schumacher exploit racial tension without understanding it.
The characters may be stereotypes to us, but they're played here with a love and tenderness and resignation that could break your heart.
Duane Hopkins has a patient eye, and catches moments of austere beauty as it scans the bleak surroundings, but his mostly young cast is left hanging by chilly direction and an inadequate script.
A British underdog comedy of no great distinction.

This unbelievably ponderous British chiller keeps priming us for some shocking revelations - oodles of "scary" incidental music, ominous shots of the London skyline - and signally fails to deliver them.
It feels no more authentic than Stauffenberg's glass eyeball.
As a public figure Van Sant does him full justice; as a private individual, tormented by a needy Latino lover (Diego Luna) the film is much vaguer.
It's Altman-esque, in good and bad ways, though by the end I confess I felt like the traditional mother of the bride, my eyes filling up helplessly even as I begged, "no more".
For most of its length, this is a grippingly unpleasant picture of barbaric, gratuitous evil, stealthier and scarier than Funny Games, to which it bears a slight resemblance.

You can't tear your eyes from it. Loosely held together by Michael Hordern's drolly ironic narration, it might not catch very much of Thackeray's tone but it creates a world that is sumptuously, even shockingly, vivid.
One feels nagged all the way by its self-proclaimed momentousness.

Soppy romance and excruciating piety cling to the film like bindweed, summoning the ghost of sobfest Pay It Forward, with the divine parallels of self-sacrifice taken to extremes of righteous absurdity.
The only drawback to its fey shaggy-dog story is the ponderous pace. But Northam and Neill are both on good form.
movie_title: Dean Spanley (My Talks with Dean Spanley) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: For all the drama that surrounded them, Soderbergh never gets under the skin of either Che Guevara or Fidel Castro. We can only hope that the psychological dimensions will be illuminated in the next part.

Nothing wrong with a film's reach exceeding its grasp, but Luhrmann's ambition has left this one looking forlorn and exposed: Australia clears a huge space for itself and then hasn't the wit or the wherewithal to fill it.

It gets a little silly, at times, particularly in the special-effects department, but Stewart and Pattinson are a quite mesmerising pair, and their twitchy, sidelong glances play out a duet of unspoken yearning that might just get under your skin.
A long story, and one more likely to work its charm on kids than on their parents.
This Austrian-German adaptation of La Bohème underlines why opera should be confined to the stage.
This soft-headed hagiography is a disappointment, and at least half an hour too long.
movie_title: Gonzo: The Life and Work of Hunter S. Thompson (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Lemon Tree offers no solution to the ancient struggles of ownership in the West Bank, but it shines a tender, humane light on the individual lives it continues to disrupt.

Adapted from the best-selling novel by Cornelia Funke, this makes a splashy fuss about "the magic of books", and yet undermines our imaginative instincts by monstering the screen with special effects.
It is almost an anti-mystery, our meagre clue to the protagonist's feelings of guilt legible in the contours of Krobot's mournful mid-European face: only Bruno Ganz, one feels, could out-gloom him.
movie_title: The Man From London (A Londoni Férfi) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Our chastened hero steers a confusing course between self-parody and self-justification. "Van Damme needs just one thing ..." runs the tag line, "... to be himself". But does anyone still care?

The movie's last quarter gets clogged up with special effects, including what looks like a gigantic swarm of locusts that eat through whole juggernauts. Whether this eco-warning will have a morally improving effect on audiences is uncertain.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Can a single performance redeem a whole movie? Heaven knows Kate Winslet does her damnedest to wrestle with the contradictions of The Reader.
This small teen romance has the snap and crackle of early Doug Liman movies (Swingers, Go) and a charm all its own.
Allow that director Gerald McMorrow's feature debut shows ambition in fusing psychodrama, fantasy and metropolitan romance. Sadly, coherence and comprehensibility have been left for dead.
The film is very astute about pride and shame, less accomplished in sustaining a coherent narrative.

In its depiction of the crucial tests of nerve, and of their rooting-out of traitors, the film recalls L'armée des Ombres, which similarly examines the psychological conflict between killing and the gravitational pull of one's humanity.
movie_title: Flammen & Citronen (Flame & Citron) (The Flame and the Lemon) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: At times it looks rather staged for camera, in the manner of reality television, but there's a lot more to like and enjoy here than you might suppose.

The demonic possession plot thereafter breaks down in a tasteless swamp of Nazi experiments on twins, dogs with inverted heads and an exorcism led by rabbi Gary Oldman. Oy vey! The kosher paranormal: a trend in the offing?

We have to munch through a load of Capra-corn as she switches from corporate hatchet-woman to champion of local business. "You know, you're not so bad when you're unconscious," says Connick Jr of her. We could probably say the same of the scriptwriter.

It's reasonably efficient, passably entertaining, and strenuously playing catch-up with the Bourne movies: flat-footed Owen doesn't look as good as Matt Damon sprinting through city streets, and the editing doesn't match Paul Greengrass's whiplash pace.
This modest-looking B-movie, first seen in 1949, has acquired a substantial following in the years since - justifiably.
This action "threequel" is directed by a gentleman named Megaton, so one should not expect subtlety.
Cantet has offered another subtly incisive study of work, class and family.
Sci-fi hokum to give you a headache.
In a way it's quite touching that Eastwood still believes a man is never too old to change. One only wishes that Gran Torino were a little more subtle and a little less earnest in its operations.
This sickening ode to consumerist greed comes just in time for the recession.
This is an honourable attempt to get at the heart of a great novel. Its account of marital failure and of lost illusions is consistently absorbing and occasionally heart-rending.
This plodding, one-paced, dramatically inert movie is almost entirely surface description.

The film accepts the bleak comedy of this, yet its refusal to patronise Anvil's endurance eventually becomes quite moving. It's a study in the blind hopefulness that just drives some people on, through every setback.
This revisiting of Peter Sellers' Inspector Clouseau catapults Martin so far beyond the pale of authentic comedy that there can be no hope of return.

Three Monkeys, could be reduced to a simple moral - never do a dodgy politician a favour - though its layering of ironies and wrong turnings render it more subtly disturbing than that précis might suggest.
The boasts get louder, the bling shinier, but the film itself just gets increasingly monotonous.

The tautness of the first hour is tremendous, and features something I never thought to see in such a movie: the spectacle of a man, hiding inside a car from his would-be killer, and doing something we would all probably do in real life: actually whimper.
movie_title: El Rey de la montaña (King of the Hill) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: This remake of the "classic" Eighties slasher serves only to highlight its timeless banality.
A sluggish narrative is further hampered by "comic" turns (Juliet Stevenson, as a gurning governess) and some frankly shameless knockoffs.
A message to women: this movie is undermining and traducing your sex.
movie_title: He's Just Not That Into You (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Some fancy setpieces here and there, and gunplay just about everywhere, but none of the principals can begin to rival the sacred trio of Eli Wallach, Lee Van Cleef and the other one.
movie_title: The Good, the Bad, the Weird (Joheun-nom, Nabbeun-nom, Isanghan-nom) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The moral grey area of the title perhaps worked better in the stage play; exposed on screen it's not "doubt" being expressed, it's the sound of Streep's headmistressy voice demanding, "That Oscar - on my desk, NOW."
The plot is sentimental fluff. But this has energy and invention enough to keep Lasseter top of the heap.
The music is great, so energetic and vital it leaves the drama looking unfocused in comparison. Beyoncé, singing her heart out, is the pick of a very impressive line-up.
Some decent performances but not enough that's distinctive to earn a recommendation.
Altogether a shambles, and perhaps uniquely in the Coward canon, it features not a single laugh.
Featuring possibly the quickest bank heist ever committed to screen, Rivals bumps along agreeably, if not scintillatingly, though Canet and Cluzet are a good match as the frères maudits.
What starts out as a hokey satire on electioneering and spin becomes a hokey lesson on civic responsibility, with a catch in the throat and a tear in the eye. Try to suppress the curl in your lip.
Redbelt, his latest, is a curious one, a movie that hints at greatness only to retreat, unpardonably, into genre convention.
what writer-director Philippe Claudel does superbly is to map the slow thawing of the icy chip at her heart.
Fast cars, machine guns, explosions, babes in hotpants - it's everything a 12-year-old boy could want in a movie.
His sepia images of war's futility are beautiful, and Vishnevskaya's face is a compelling one, but they cannot compensate for the soporific anti-narrative.
Instead, it's a rather pompous, disappointing one, and a squandered opportunity to boot.
If Hogg can render the travails of a bunch of middle-class British holidaymakers a subject of interest, there's reason to hope she has some career in the making.
It's so flat and unfunny it makes Sex and the City sound like Billy Wilder.
Rohmer's gentle philosophical chat is better heard, I think, among the muddled middle-classes of late-20th century France.

The first half-hour floats by on a cloud of mildly funny lines ("couscous - the food so nice they named it twice"), but then slumps into a derivative action caper that's weirdly and unappealingly reminiscent of Eighties dross like Beverly Hills Cop.
If feeling alone were the benchmark of great art, Vic Sarin's film would be considerable, but the screenplay is desperately poor and the direction leaden.
The only puzzle of this toxically stupid Europhobe thriller is that its director (Pierre Morel) and producer (Luc Besson) are both French.
The burden of this Icelandic procedural thriller will put a chill in your bones, if the lugubrious, wind-whipped coastal setting hasn't done already.
Writer-director Mark Herman has done a creditable job of negotiating its volatile compound of fable and realism.
movie_title: The Boy in the Striped Pajamas (The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Wong Kar-Wai's 1994 epic, remodelled and reissued, looks spectacular, but trying to follow its storyline is a test.
At once epic and intimate, Sweet Land offers a stirring account of love and hardship which, aside from a muffed Capra moment towards the end, hardly puts a foot wrong.
His fortitude under critical flak is admirable, and his self-confidence unbelievable, but RocknRolla is the same old shaggy-dog story with a slightly different variety fleas.
McDowell's affectionate, mischievous impersonations and clips from Anderson's body of work make for an easy couple of hours.
movie_title: Never Apologize: A Personal Visit With Lindsay Anderson (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Can we not just enjoy what's on the screen without being spoon-fed a specious modern analogy? Dibb and his team - especial plaudits to Michael Carlin's production design and Michael O'Connor's costumes - have worked honourably to persuade us that we can.
I wish to God they would find something else to do.
But even if you don't tire of the relentless violence, you might want to call time on Cage's tough-but-sensitive übermensch.
The film's forlorn charm is a little reminiscent of Cameron Crowe's adolescent memoir Almost Famous. It's a tiny bit soppy, too, but you can forgive that in a teenager.

The film is concerned with observing the passage of time, the change in the light, the immemorial contours of the landscape, and, in one shot, a very touching pieta of a boy and his new baby sibling. Compelling stuff if you can stay with it.
Its influences, from The Conversation to The Shining, are worn like cheap tattoos, while its jittery editing and blurred photography fail to hide the yawning emptiness at its centre.
Daily Mail scaremongering? Possibly. But formidably well-made, all the same.
This ghastly ode to female companionship apparently derives from a bestselling novel, but it feels more like something stitched together from other sorority movies.

It's not much to offer a newcomer, who would be best advised to read Waugh's novel; failing that, to get hold of the TV serial. Either would be preferable to this copy of a copy, and a rather inadequately handled one at that.

Unlike the 1994 basketball doc Hoop Dreams, which investigated collateral issues of education, race and money, this merely sets a twitchy hip-hop soundtrack to an unenlightening parade of eager sporting wannabes.
The visual invention and draughtsmanship are mightily impressive; a shame the drama's a bit of a bore.

Lakeside Terrace allows the antagonism to simmer just so, and then, regrettably, lets it boil over in a climax of gunplay and a swathe of Californian brush fires, perhaps the most crashingly symbolic conflagration since Apocalypse Now.
Swinton's Julia is one of those performances that goes so far in repelling audience sympathy that it comes out the other side looking almost admirable.
There's a prissy self-congratulation about early parts of David Auburn's family-bereavement drama, though it got to me eventually.
The screenplay is stewed in such pieties, served up as warm and homely as apple pie - only there's no taste to it.
The idea of cosseted middle-class tots becoming feral psychopaths has potential, though most of it is squandered by uncertain direction and some unconvincing psychology.
A powerfully ambiguous meditation on personal and collective avoidance.
But it's something of a penance to sit through, a token handwringing over American dirty tricks that's just another opportunity for Scott and co to blow stuff up.
It's prurient, sentimental, and baffling to boot.
Rogen does his man-child-slob shtick dependably, and Elizabeth Banks is a good sport as well as a decent comedian. One only wishes that the whole thing were funnier.
movie_title: Zack and Miri Make a Porno (2008)

movie_review_blurb: There's an inevitable staginess to Tennessee Williams' devastating portrait of delusion and cruelty, but director Elia Kazan catches the squalid, claustrophobic atmosphere of a New Orleans tenement just right.
Admire it, at least, as a kids' film trying to be different, but even at 90 minutes, it drags.
Perhaps it's a tad overstretched at 110 minutes, but the film's performances and the sly, satirical tone are unfailingly attractive.

His approach has simply been to cram everything he knows about the Baader Meinhof years into a running time of two and a half hours. It is really the most unhelpful and unenlightening film on the subject you could possibly imagine.
movie_title: Der Baader Meinhof Komplex (The Baader Meinhof Complex) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The vicissitudes of Qing dynasty politics in the mid-19th century remain rather confusing, and the bloodiness of the battles is relentless, but the film has something to say about the spiritual corruption that afflicts men who live by war.
This boasts of being "a first of its kind 3D movie event", but it's just the same old torture porn tarted up.
This bad-apple cop drama is the kind of movie that Sidney Lumet used to make in the Seventies and Eighties, and it hasn't evolved a great deal since.
French writer-director Agnès Jaoui's comedy of manners takes on issues of class, race and loyalty, but in such a charming, offhand way that one hardly notices them being raised.
movie_title: Let it Rain (Parlez-moi de la pluie) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Director Peter Cattaneo will probably never repeat his Full Monty success, but even in its mediocre patches one senses a renewed eagerness to entertain.
The screenwriter, Laura Santullo, is slightly heavy-handed at times, but she expertly captures the mood of paranoia and self-righteousness gripping this middle-class enclave.
This dark-toned animation borrows its style from Tim Burton's Nightmare Before Christmas and Corpse Bride without adding much of its own to the macabre mayhem.
The brief relationship that the escaped elephant forms with a resourceful moose is oddly touching, but the fatuities surrounding it ensure that any deeper involvement is unlikely.
Portentous nonsense, and loud with it.
One could be forgiven for thinking that the American college system is merely one big popularity contest. Certainly, no one does anything outrageous like read a book.
It's meant to be a portrait of a man "choked" by his own alienation, but Jorge's shyness comes over as dullness, and after all the sensitive maundering the conclusion is a terrible letdown.
It's a fiendish little thriller, and undeniably sick, but you won't forget it in a hurry.
The cerebral cool of Schrader's perspective sacrifices emotional connection to its subject.
movie_title: Mishima: A Life in Four Chapters (1985)

movie_review_blurb: Williams, with pageboy haircut and a martyrishly sad face, is quite lovely as this lost soul, while writer-director Kelly Reichardt catches something poignant in the windblown spaces of the American north-west.
An indie sci-fi movie? That's what the director Duncan Jones has put together, to mostly inspired effect.

Director Gregor Jordan seems to have gone into reverse since his 2001 Buffalo Soldiers, aiming for the LA rondeau of Altman's Short Cuts but missing all the vital ingredients - wit, humanity, charm, nuance and meaning.
A modest but thrilling drama.
It's guerilla film-making of amazing courage.
movie_title: Burma VJ: Reporter i et Lukket Land (Burma VJ: Reporting from a Closed Country) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: This film is a bit like a summer cold: you just have to sit there while it runs its course.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It's well-acted, sensitive, and a tad melodramatic in its lurch from one crisis to another, but you'd forgive it a lot more for Wright Penn's magnificent portrait of unaffected goodness.
movie_title: The Private Lives of Pippa Lee (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Unseen for 35 years, its spectacle is undimmed, and you can pick many highlights.
Claire Denis's film-making is so elliptical you sometimes feel at a loss to know what's going on, but the mood - cool, meditative, unhurried - beckons you along insistently.
A puerile, remedial class version of Wedding Crashers.
For a while their stupid rivalry, insults and petulant displays of outrage are funny, but like the talented child who won't be quiet for a second, the act eventually begins to grate.
Dresen's unpatronising focus upon a neglected generation almost contains the air of a radical experiment.
It's so outlandish that at times you wonder if Von Trier himself knows what's going on. It would not be surprising to learn that he's making it all up as he goes along.

Of course, there are laughs, and if audacity were the only principle by which film-making achievement were judged the movie would be a knockout. But having groaned and winced through most of its 83 minutes I couldn't wait to get out of there.
This medical-ethics drama is like a sustained assault on the tear ducts.
This tale of two brothers seems to be a comic satire on ambition, but the laughs are desperately hard to come by.
Ramis has got his comic premise, but instead of constructing a plot, he and his co-writers work up only some feeble vignettes.
Cary Grant's suave adman Roger O Thornhill finds himself in mortal peril as the innocent man-on-the-run, yet the tone throughout is buoyantly, almost insolently, comic.
Fourteen-year-old boys will get their money's worth. This boring, preposterous nonsense is stretched to an agonising two-and-a-half hours.
The film's message of "healing" couldn't be more sincere, but it can't cover for the awkward staging, cheap lighting and stilted script.
It's kooky, it's quirky, it's dippy, it's trippy, it's loopy, it's screwy - it's indie, and boy, it's annoying.
Some nice moments, though not all that convincing in its lament for a great lost talent.
Though it would be hard to call it life-affirming. It is too riven with grief and horror for that, too aware of what Poland has suffered for it to be anything but a deeply sombre memorial.

The battle choreography is superb, and Woo's Peckinpah-style slo-mo violence ensures that every lopping and skewering gets our full attention. The film could do with some lopping itself - at least half an hour - but the effect is dizzyingly grand.
Laverty has a proven track record as a grim social realist; he is less assured as a comic fantasist; and he is absolutely hopeless when he tries to combine the two.

It's not on a par with Little Miss: there's some whimsical-tragical stuff about talking to the dead via CB radio, and the producers might want to think beyond using "Sunshine" in a title again. But I would have been sorry to miss this.
Director Iliadis creates undeniably tense moments in, but the depravity is so gratuitously in-your-face that even a seasoned film critic might baulk.
movie_title: The Last House on the Left (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Another dagger in the back of romantic comedy.
The lure of a new life kickstarts this gripping Danish noir-romance.
movie_title: Kærlighed på Film (Just Another Love Story) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The pace is oddly sluggish, the flashbacks are awkward, and most of the risque lines die a death, but there are two reasons to stay with it - Rust himself as the super-dweeb hero and Jack T Carpenter as his movie-quoting best friend.

Fans of their Scary Movie and its sequels know what to expect, though perhaps even they will notice here a thinning in the comedy and a coarsening in its misogynist and homophobic riffs. Not an honest laugh in 90 minutes.
Too much of its urban grit seems in thrall to American precedents.
The writer-director Antonio Campos uses his camera in catatonically slow movements, to varying effect: sometimes it feels probing, at others it looks like so much film school self-indulgence.
If the accomplishment of this first scene were upheld throughout then we might have a masterpiece on our hands. Alas, it is uneven as well as unpredictable.
They've tried to cloak a very dull love story in pseudo-poetic significance. You might feel like disappearing yourself.
A striking, and often quite gruelling, account of survival and flight in poverty-stricken Central America.
How would it be if Eddie Murphy quit making trashy, ingratiating comedies and grew up? Imagine that.
Not perfect, by any means, but a top night out
Graff has wonderfully captured not just the emotional havoc of adolescence but its passionate belief in music as a life-changing force.
A pleasant, inconsequential movie.
Cut it by an hour and it could be a good and useful introduction to Dickens for English GCSE students, but in its present form this has no place on a cinema screen anywhere.
A squall of improbabilities leads to a laughable late revelation, yet somehow the film keeps a clammy grip.
There's an inevitable air of unfinished business hanging over this first instalment, though it moves at a tidy lick and conjures an atmosphere rank with Gauloises and greed.
movie_title: Mesrine: Part 1 (Killer Instinct) and Part 2 (Public Enemy #1) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: What I hated most of all was the script , which smears these so-called insights into the sex wars with pointless (and witless) crudity. More depressing still, it's written by three women.

The narrative lags some way behind the beautiful nature photography and the comical majesty of the meerkat on guard, poking his head above a hidey-hole like a periscope over a parapet. These pictures don't really need any words.
I was more excited by last week's G-Force 3-D, if only because the guinea pigs give the better performances.
movie_title: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Compare him with the gang-leader in the 1974 film, played by Robert Shaw as a tight-lipped, ice-cool killer, and Travolta starts to look like a joke.

It's a kind of cut-price Jurassic Park, with a support cast of gabbling monkeys and lizardish humanoids, and if they don't seem far-fetched you might believe Anna Friel as a Cambridge- educated scientist.
One or two of the ideas are actually not bad - there's a rather cute joke about a mole, for instance - but for the most part, it's like running on a wheel.

As with many multi-character pieces, it's somewhat unbalanced by its competing storylines, and its lapses into sentimentality seem inevitable, but Kramer deserves credit for taking on a touchy subject.
Unlike her famous designs, this lacks structure, texture and interest.
The early scenes are slightly stiff, and the acting uncertain, but this story of estrangement is sufficiently remarkable in itself.
Sergio Leone's frontier parable is a landmark in Westerns, and features not only one of the greatest opening sequences ever made, but also the best use of a harmonica in cinema.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in the West (1968)

movie_review_blurb: Home is actually less a road movie than the domestic-invasion movie taken to its sick conclusion.

Dark arterial blood pools across pavements and leaks under doorways, as though to chasten us. Unfortunately, after two and half hours of this sanguinary spectacle it wasn't catharsis I felt; it was simple weariness.
Some very funny, very non-PC dialogue is thrown about like a game of catch. The actors, virtually unknown, are terrific.
If Shaun of the Dead is the gold standard of British zombie comedy, and Lesbian Vampire Killers is a tin-plated knock-off, then Doghouse must be ... Ratners.
Cue a not very dazzling chase movie.
Let the Right One In manages its own sense of doubleness with uncommon daring: you don't see many love stories that bring together pubescence and vampirism in such an elegant clinch.
"Ride or die, remember?" Er, not really, no. More like "Yawn and forget", as Nabokov once recommended. Only 13-year-old boys and Jeremy Clarkson could possibly enjoy this.
Sturgess is superb as the double-dealer, nailing the Ulster accent and conveying the self-disgust behind McGartland's cocky front; Kingsley too gives good value in one of his less showy roles.
It's a cornerstone of the French New Wave, and one of the greatest movies about childhood, from anywhere, ever.
It's silly, but the generational love matches it entrains.
A rather tame live-action sci-fi flick.
It is a rollicking entertainment for some of the time, and a sulphurous study in bare-faced cynicism pretty much all of the time. An achievement of sorts, though I wish I could have liked it more.

British documentarist Phil Grabsky puts together an elegant if unchallenging chronicle of the composer's life, running through the highs and occasional lows while making free with long excerpts from the work.
Writer-director John Hamburg drastically misjudges audience sympathy here, because Syd isn't cool at all.
Mortensen isn't bad, though he looks merely absent-minded rather than anguished.
Deeply unedifying, but it has some moves.
It doesn't add up to much as a story, but as an account of a demi-monde defiant in its loucheness and loneliness it has its moments of odd grace.
However much you admire the daring of these young surfers, you soon realise that listening to them yarn on about the sport can become very, very boring.
It's pretty easy to take the piss out of religious kitsch, as Maher does. It would have been more instructive (if less chucklesome) if he'd risked an argument with an accredited theologian.
Aficianadoes of 1950s monster movies should have a ball spotting all the references. All anyone else requires is a taste for good fun.
Raymond Depardon's documentary catches a poignant sense of lives, and livelihoods, inexorably dwindling.
movie_title: Profils Paysans: la Vie Moderne (Modern Life) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: For a man who loves the raucous, ebullient pop of the 1960s, Curtis's own output has been terribly, terminally square. This latest is a new low: The Film That Sucked.

It never feels quite believable, though Phoenix is touching in the central role. If this really is his screen swansong - he apparently intends to pursue a musical career - then it will be the movies' loss.
Before it reverts to standard thriller tropes, this tale of an Islamic double agent takes a more thoughtful attitude to East-West relations than one might expect.
I suspect the director was aiming for a sun-blessed version of Don't Look Now, but his ghost story conjures neither suspense nor intrigue.
This is the Life of Brian, and nobody else's. As such, it's never dull, and in many little details it's a back-of-the-net pleasure.
The CGI is unconvincing, the big shock-and-awe finale is a throwback to the days of Deep Impact, and underneath it all is the nervous American insistence that there is life beyond the stars.
All the period trappings -decor, duds, dances - are immaculate, though presented in the manner of a set-text reconstruction rather than a living, breathing drama.
This tale of forbidden love in the early days of apartheid South Africa suffers from heavy-handed direction and stodgy exposition, but it is made tolerable by its two central performances.
It serves up the science of this potential catastrophe in firm, digestible chunks, though it perhaps didn't require the gloopy New Age music as garnish.
This is Herzog in awe at life, the universe, eternity itself.
movie_title: Encounters at the End of the World (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Do you need to be told it's preposterous? Probably not. But you may be pleasantly surprised to hear it's also quite enjoyable.
The story's slow-burn never quite flares into dramatic wildfire.
A tense drama of the deadly cat-and-mouse between the resistance and the Nazis.

Both are about one notch off in their impersonation of "ordinary" people - it reminded me of Streep and De Niro in Falling in Love. Nothing offensive about it, apart from its sense of London geography.
The Hide is a modestly scaled but cleverly written chamber piece.
The last half-hour is fraught with near-unbearable tension, as the writer-director Fred Cavaye runs the escape plot alongside the concerted efforts of les flics to foil it.

The overall effect is so full of loathing and meanness that one hardly cares for those subliminal tremors, and the arch structuring of the story - the accident, then the long flashback - makes it dramatically inert.
They have equipped Terminator Salvation with so little heart or personality that it would be no surprise to learn that computers had put it together.
The elegiac tenderness and pictorial beauty of Gideon Koppel's film becomes, by degrees, quite compelling.
Bunny boilers ahoy. This lame and laughable stalker-thriller makes Fatal Attraction look thoughtful.
Jeremy Podeswa's tremulous adaptation of Anne Michaels's novel aches with earnest intent and tasteful eroticism, yet it moves as heavily and lugubriously as a prison gate.
An agonisingly sincere drama of familial dysfunction, this is notable for some very basic miscasting.
One or two amusing moments, but not sustainable for 90 minutes.
movie_title: Frequently Asked Questions About Time Travel (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Cheap, nasty and rather magnificent.
It's sort of Grange Hill meets Friday the 13th, with Stephen Prentice's script going for laughs and larks amid the slaughter.

In Mark Of An Angel the misdirection is sometimes subtle, sometimes not so, but director Safy Nebbou in the end deserves the benefit of the doubt for just about preserving credibility when the plot goes into a wild reverse skid.
movie_title: L'Empreinte de l'ange (Mark of an Angel) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: One keeps hoping that some of that sinister Chabrolian wit will enliven the film's smooth surface, but alas, it never does.
movie_title: La Fille Coupée en Deux (The Girl Cut in Two) (A Girl Cut in Two) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It's a mark of Troell's mastery that we could happily have borne another half-hour of his mesmerising yarn.
movie_title: Maria Larssons eviga ögonblick (Everlasting Moments) (Maria Larsson's Everlasting Moment) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Its themes of friendship and rejection are handled with aching sincerity, but they cannot galvanise a drama too forgiving - and too much in awe - of knife-wielding yobs.
It's still strictly insufferable.
movie_title: Night at the Museum 2: Battle of the Smithsonian (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The brawls have a brutal energy, and Howard's performance is magnetic, but one gains little sense of character from the improvised dialogue or Tatum's sub-Brando mumbling.
Angels and Demons proves every bit as swollen and portentous as The Da Vinci Code. It is, however, nine minutes shorter than that film, so there's something to be grateful for.
Yikes, or rather, yawn. Hokum factor - 10.
It's a prestige picture all the way, supercompetent, polished, watchable - but oddly unexciting.
Drug crime on the outskirts of London sounds neither promising nor original, but Eran Creevy's debut feature is more character study than the usual Britcrim parade of guns and geezers.
Cena has neither the ease nor the appeal of Dwayne Johnson - the one true Rock - and the film's steroidal pastiche of 1990s thrillers (Speed and Die Hard with a Vengeance) is faintly embarrassing.
This "issue" movie from Belgian director Nic Balthazar throws a dramatic feint so improbable one can almost see a cartoon question mark floating above the audience's heads.
Liberal Hollywood sends its big guns into the "war on terror" and winds up in a dreadful mess.
The French director François Ozon has taken Elizabeth Taylor's beadily satiric novel and transformed it into a droll and somewhat disturbing fantasia on the creative temperament.
It begins all at sea, and, figuratively speaking, pretty much stays there.
The loveliest period piece imaginable.
Ayckbourn's play might have made frothy fun of this comedie humaine, on screen this feels a poor, airless thing.
A garbled account of state-aided terror that sheds little light on these dogs of war.
While Travolta may be the box-office pull, it's Walken who is a revelation. Hairspray is lucky to have him, and so are we.
Not a friendly film, but in the consciousness of suffering, the search for meaning and the acceptance of death, all (or nearly all) of Bergman is in it.
At least I hope it's the last. Willis does OK for a middle-aged guy, but as another famous die-hard once said, a man's got to know his limitations.
I admit that I didn't see the daft last-minute twist coming, and sort of admired it, but for the rest you'd need an extravagant love of hokum not to feel mildly bored.
It plays like a low-cal Falling Down, with all the rage of Michael Douglas's office malcontent but none of his dark humour. Possibly the weakest thing Mamet has ever written.
His camera, whether focused upon acts of horrific brutality or humdrum routine, maintains a steady, unflinching gaze. This, it seems to say, is life and death and nothing else.
It's also elegantly shot and scored; all that's missing is a touch of humour.
movie_title: Onna ga kaidan wo agaru toki (When a Woman Ascends the Stairs) (1963)

movie_review_blurb: One very expensive flop.
Competently handled, decently acted and contains a couple of twists in the final reel that may give you a jolt.
It moves, but it never flies.
Hostel: Part II does succumb to mere ghoulishness in the last-reel bloodbath, but up to that point its moral tension feels horribly persuasive.
The details of this chaotic odyssey to the New World are so intricately and poignantly handled that throughout a voice in your head insists: this is how it must have been.

While Pollack continually favours celebrity gush over objective analysis, the shots of Gehry's buildings - the Guggenheim in Bilbao being the centrepiece - and his stunning use of light do make a case for him as a genuine visionary.
I came round to them by the end, but it's not a great introduction.
movie_title: Dixie Chicks - Shut Up and Sing (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Veteran writer Larry Cohen has shown a knack for claustrophobic thrillers (Phone Booth), but this tawdry effort is almost entirely lacking in stealth and suspense.
The beats here aren't bad, they're just slow, slight and rather predictable.
The droll opening, set in a restaurant where the pecking order is rigorously observed, gives way to a complicated but uninvolving cat-and-mouse game between the police and rival gangs.

The details of the composition, the fluidity of the camera's movement and the magical elision between personal grief and "performed" grief are so confidently organised that one detects the shadow of a much subtler film. I wish that we could have seen it.
Herzog remains a one-off in German cinema - eccentric, infuriating, cherishable - and nothing in this will detract from his legend.
Fabienne Berthaud's low-budget squib tells us little we didn't know about the fashion industry, but does have Diane Kruger (Troy) as its luminous centre.
It would be a good idea for those involved to quit while they're still (just about) winning.
Pilger's portentous voiceover and intrusions into shot bespeak an excruciating vanity
An insight into the flawed nature of a great man.
The Walker might have meant something, but it tails off into vagueness.
Quite the most pretentious piffle I've seen all year.
The observation of their insecurity and antagonism is very accurate; my problem is that it's not all that funny.
A shame that it ends on this one false note, but up to that point 3.10 To Yuma fairly races along.
Sadly, the final reel exposes Wan's true colours (he directed the horror movie Saw), the vigilante machismo betraying this as an updated version of Death Wish.
Accomplished as it is, the film has trouble marrying the separate halves of the story, the mystery of the mother's death and the weird courtship Hallam is pursuing.
This slight, intermittently funny squib is a promising signpost.
Hie me to the vomitorium, it's a fantastically smug and boring movie about food and romance, pumped with artificial sweeteners.
Oddball comedy about a lonely, dog-loving secretary, Peggy (played, with unsettling intensity, by Molly Shannon).
A sombre game of cat-and-mouse. What it lacks in genuine tension it amply compensates in the understated performances of the two leads.
John Cusack's edgy, likeable performance carries this paranormal chiller, based on a Stephen King story and highly reminiscent of his landmark shockfest The Shining.
The tension occasionally goes slack, but hardly anything surpasses that clifftop finale for freakish terror.
Like Irving's book, it doesn't hold up.
In Gary Love's determinedly gritty Brit-crim movie, three good actors chase around a script that keeps promising more than it delivers.
If the essence of great comedy is truth then Knocked Up falls some way short.
Not the soft-core romp one might expect but a drama of thoughtful, touching poignancy.
Like the brutal climate it portrays, the film isn't easy to love, and Pfening makes a less sympathetic soul in torment than Trapero perhaps intends.
Having set up its line of murder suspects the film sheers off into supernatural hokum and never really recovers.
The film wants to be your cuddly, quirky friend, and makes you feel bad for not returning the affection.
A melancholy rumination on the failed hopes of Eastern Europe after the Cold War, infused with a sense of farce and the irrecoverable nature of the past.
movie_title: 12:08 East of Bucharest (A fost sau n-a fost?) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Streamlined, brisk and tight.
If the composer's shade could hear the words this script has put in his mouth it really would be a case of "roll over, Beethoven", right there in his grave.
Gatlif seems literally to make it up as he goes along, a modus operandi that works fine in the impromptu musical interludes but fails utterly in terms of drama.
Only the prospect of the outtakes and Chan's flubbed chopsocky stunts kept me going to the end, and even they turned out to be duds.
Robin Williams is back in this horrifically embarrassing and misconceived wedding comedy.
Von Ancken at times brings his debut very close to something grand and memorable.
Kenneth Branagh gamely continues to put Shakespeare on film, and audiences continue to ignore them.
The supporting cast of Nathalie Baye, Kristin Scott Thomas and Francois Berléand supply gloss to the picture, though its plotting becomes so convoluted that tension drains away
movie_title: Ne le Dis à Personne (Tell No One) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: One could wish that this parable of difference and tolerance gladdened the heart, but its effortful comedy has quite the opposite effect. It's just weedy.
The best jokes are the true jokes, and truth has not been best served here.
The film isn't that risky, and the romantic obstacles thrown in the couple's way feel a little perfunctory.
So skilfully does the film shield its hand that the final "reveal" actually comes as a disappointment - the enigma was truly much harder to bear.

Some will dismiss it as "typical Hollywood", yet that isn't always a bad thing. In so many movies, destruction and loss are dwelt upon because they are irreducible truths. But survival is a truth, too, and this film pays it often stirring witness.
When all else fails, get the pensioners to swear.
"Muddled" is the polite word, balderdash the preferred one.
You can understand why somebody would want to make a film about such a famous "lost moment" in American history, but this celebrity ensemble piece is misconceived and poorly managed.
One can detect almost the spirit of a public information film nagging the audience: look, people, the American Dream doesn't come for free.
The identity swaps, double-crosses and multiple shoot-em-ups are reminiscent of The Usual Suspects and early Tarantino, without the ingenuity of the former or the breakneck energy of the latter.
So often the gentle giant, Whitaker changes tack here with an intimidating display of girth and guile, mixed in with the outward signals of untouchable nuttiness.
Broomfield, inspired by Ken Loach and perhaps too by Michael Winterbottom in his exposure of the migrants' plight, has made a film surprising in its intensity and compassion.
The same impish [Spaced] spirit is uncorked here, but it has been fatally indulged.
Newell handles this unfamiliar material competently enough, but the film never picks up any true momentum.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A nicely played family entertainment with perhaps more mystery than it knows what to do with.
What Mortensen does brilliantly is to keep us guessing.
This might be Plasticine's finest hour.
movie_title: Wallace & Gromit: The Curse of the Were-Rabbit (2005)

movie_review_blurb: While there's no denying Miyazaki's visual flair and tip-top draughtsmanship, I found myself less than enchanted by the mile-high convolutions of the plot, and frankly bored by the final half-hour.

Time was when movie-makers, even laws-unto- themselves such as Sam Peckinpah, could be trusted to examine the consequences of living every moment in mortal danger: violence meant something more to them than simple connoisseurship.

Oh, the relief to reach the conclusion of Star Wars Episode III, not because George Lucas has brought home the franchise safe and sound but because I know I will never have to sit through another minute of this turgid, subliterate spaceballs again.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Its high-mindedness has obscured the thriller's basic function -- to deliver thrills.
DiCaprio remains a lightweight presence, a cherubic man-child who one could sooner imagine fiddling with an Airfix set and glue than spearheading the adventure of modern aviation.
Cuaron has imbued a touch of the night into Harry and rendered the series a good deal more intriguing.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)

movie_review_blurb: While Shrek 2 bowls merrily along on the fuel of firecracker wit and knowing pastiche that made the original so memorable, it will come as no surprise that second time around we don't feel quite so discombobulated by its brilliance.
No denying his energy, but it's like the energy of a kid with attention deficit disorder: his stories can't settle on anything for more than a few minutes.
movie_title: Shorts: The Adventures of the Wishing Rock (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Shark Tale is no disaster, but despite the efforts of three directors, two screenwriters and phalanxes of technicians, it seems to be treading water.
director Nimrod Antal settles for a more generic horror-ride as the imperatives of stalk-and-escape take hold. For a while, though, this is first-rate second-hand material.
The film has no real thematic ambition beyond restating the old "war is hell" adage.

At one point Daphne warns Milly, "You're going to end up like some pathetic character in a Tennessee Williams play." If ever a film could have used a character from a Tennessee Williams play, it's this one.
It's all quite harmless, the shape-shifting plot does not extend much beyond 90 minutes, and Alba still looks good in a jumpsuit. We've seen it before, we'll see it again.
movie_title: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Oh, I do hope so. Why Ice Cube thought his wretched family outing Are We There Yet? deserved a sequel is baffling, since all it revealed was his complete ineptitude as a light comedian.
"The most important film of the decade", this calls itself, though "most self-righteous" might be closer to the truth.

The only film worth seeing this week is Not Here To Be Loved, a modest French comedy that has more expressive subtlety and romance in it than Soderbergh and co will ever manage, even unto Ocean's Umpteen.
John Boorman's tale of doppelgängers in Dublin would like very much to spook us, but keeps tripping over its loose script and bizarre plot lines.

Despite the top-drawer cast assembled for his debut feature, the director Arie Posin's account of emotional dislocation in the 'burbs is stymied by a fatally uneven tone and a growing suspicion that we've been down this road many, many times before.
There is one small bit of good news about Ocean's Thirteen: it's not as bad as Ocean's Twelve. But when you consider just how dismal the latter was, this nugget will hardly be cause for rejoicing.
If you don't buy Fair Trade coffee after this you never will.
Don't go down to the basement, you idiot, there's a slavering hound waiting to attack you.
It is so preposterous it could almost be the spoof "bad action movie" they'd keep flashing to in a Hollywood satire.
Being this unfunny should be illegal.
Buñuel was, among other things, the great dirty surrealist of cinema.
An affecting but uneven memoir of council-estate Britain in the summer of 1983.

movie_title: Le Premier Jour du Reste de ta Vie (The First Day of the Rest of Your Life) (2008)
