movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Greengrass, with his superkinetic camerawork and visceral sense of you-are-there immediacy, pieces together a compelling picture of a ground force trying (and failing) to order a city on the slide towards anarchy.
When revelation of the story's soggy mysteries is finally fished out from the murk it's so underwhelming you'd be tempted to throw it right back into the water.
This I-Don't-Know-How-I-Do-It schtick may appeal to the martyred-motherhood brigade, but it won't do anything for people who turn up to a comedy expecting laughs.
More apocalyptic twaddle, this time the setting a scuzzy diner named Paradise Falls - groan - on the edge of the Mojave Desert.
The arguments propounded on behalf of the environment look faultless, but they could be distilled into a 10-minute video campaign rather than stretched beyond an hour.
The sense of intrigue is unmistakable, and fortunately Exit, an odd, enfolded sort of documentary, delivers on all the build-up.
It is the kind of film that falls over itself trying to dazzle us, and makes an unholy mess of the vital workaday stuff. It is silly, tedious, tasteless and utterly false.
Like Chekhov dumbed down for a tea-time serial.
A cleverly oblique movie.
movie_title: La Mujer sin Cabeza (The Headless Woman) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The first-time writer-director Scott Cooper sets a gentle, unhurried pace as he unfolds the story.
The plot is stagey, and the denouement ridiculous, but its sheer unlikeliness is what also keeps you hanging in there.
A few of the more lyrical touches don't quite come off, but in general this has a visual and dramatic punch that does credit both to its young star and its first-time director.

At first sight Garry Marshall's all-star ensemble looks to be a Short Cuts-lite - Short Cutlets, if you will - until it establishes its tone of flabby sentimentality and you realise it's more like an LA version of Love, Actually.
No animator captures the movement of tides and the deep physics of the sea as lyrically as Miyazaki, and the story's themes of rejuvenation and ecological balance carry a highly topical edge.
If they'd played it for laughs it might just have worked, but in fact its earnest tone and digimation effects stick pretty close to the Potter model. We could be in for a very long haul.
movie_title: Percy Jackson & the Olympians: The Lightning Thief (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A weepie like they don't make them like anymore.
Hopelessly inert and dreary.
movie_title: Why Did I Get Married Too (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It doesn't help that Zellweger has become so hard to like, horribly smug and pious when things are going right, abjectly hysterical when she sees the error of her ways.
Baumbach is capable of brilliant dialogue, and certain scenes have a tidy truthfulness that recall Woody Allen at his pinnacle.

Burton, once a master of CGI, has gradually become its servant, or at least has allowed the studio to. The madcap ringmaster of Gothic phantasmagoria does not exert his individual stamp on a book one might have thought he was born to film.

The cumulative effect of this film is to enhance one's respect for The Doors (John Densmore, Robby Krieger and Ray Manzarek) and to diminish the same for Morrison, whose posturing now looks like the most fatuous exhibitionism.
For the most part, though, it's way too broad, and its tacit assumption that the heroine is too stupid to twig she's been played is fairly monstrous. Perhaps you just have to be French.
Francis Veber's 1998 Le Dîner de Cons was no great shakes, but it looks almost classy next to this atrocious remake.
Its suggestion of a conscienceless underclass will be as a red rag to more conservative souls, but you suspect Williams won't care. He's becoming a real player in the cinema of ordeal.
Among several masterly setpieces, the long ballroom scene, with its sinuous movement and hundreds of extras, is an imperishable glory.
Quote not available.
The ghost of Alan Clarke's Scum makes its presence felt in this lowering tale of a youth correctional facility in the American Midwest.
The film shows its comic-book origins in good ways (stylish settings) and bad (too many scenes end in a gigantic conflagration).
One for the kids, if they're really misbehaving.
In its ambition to weld a political message onto a comic-book movie it falls rather pitifully between two stools.
What began as an enjoyably perverse fable of teen romance and chastity has dwindled, by this third instalment, into a sorry, soppy saga.
This, the latest variation on the "follow your dream" dance fantasy, draws an ever sharper line between tip-top street dance and bottom-of-the-class dialogue and acting.
In which a bunch of macho has-beens and never-weres splash down in the action pond for one last go-round.
Sandler's abysmal script cooks up a bite-sized moral for the finale. Groan ups, more like.
Frontier blues, indeed, but nothing you can sing along to.
It's silly but not unwatchable, and has the nous not to take itself too seriously...
The plot of Phillip Noyce's spy thriller is continually and unutterably absurd, yet for the first hour, when Salt goes on the run from the Agency, packs a fair few thrills.
Quote not available.
The last reel isn't nearly so involving as the first, but there's plenty here to encourage hope for what Wheatley and Hill try next.
Beguiles almost to the last frame.
"Overkill is underrated," says team-leader Hannibal Smith (Liam Neeson), ominously, and the next two hours proceed to give overkill its due.
It becomes clear that Stone is ill-equipped to conduct a serious political analysis of the continent.
How Harald Zwart, the director, justified bulking the film up to 140 minutes defies understanding.
It's a brave variation on the biopic, but not a compelling one.

The director Claire Denis shuffles timeframes to no great purpose, though her real error is failing to spot the insoluble contradiction in Huppert's character: how can a woman so resourceful be so blind to the realities around her?
Oh dear.
It has universal appeal, and something important and meaningful to say.
Shut Up Anthony isn't a calamity, it's just one of those movies with an interesting premise that's squandered by an unlikable main character and a slow pace.
You'll dig this movie a ton, because it's basically a master filmmaker taking a stroll down memory lane and exploring what makes his work stand out.
Beauty and the Beast lacks both the charm and the aesthetic splendor of its predecessor; it's a meaningless and empty remake that, for the most part, just poorly mimics the original's iconic scenes.
Mark my words; it'll be a modern classic.
The Belko Experiment takes itself terrifyingly seriously, making for a nerve-racking experience in terror.
It's not a terrible film, and it will find its audience who will no doubt love it, but to me it's just another Woody Allen flick in a sea of Woody Allen flicks.
I was a kid and this was my first exposure to the franchise, I'm sure I'd be hooked. For everyone else, this just doesn't have enough power.
Hopefully this film will be successful and we'll see a more solid sophomore film, but as a debut film Onah should be commended.

It has a ton of heart and a bevy of interesting interviewees who paint a clear and coherent picture of who Bert Berns was inside and outside of the music biz... It's a must see for any fan, new or old.
It's an unconventional movie that's captivating, powerful, and entertaining down to its very last moments.
When the film strays from all of the recognizable conventions, it really shines and feels like something special.
[Prevenge is] a thought-provoking, visually stunning film with just the right amount of humor to balance out some very gruesome and shocking death scenes.
I feel the third act is not nearly as strong as the first two, but the climax is damned near perfect and a great send off for Jackman and the Wolverine character.
Visually, Moana is a gorgeous film.
It's perfect for watching with a group of your friends who appreciate B-movies.
Folk Hero & Funny Guy has a lot of heart; it's a feel-good movie with a mesmerizing charm that makes it a definite watch.
To this film's credit, it's a hell of a lot more fun that any of the Underworld movies.
If you're into crime dramas, this might be your lukewarm cup of tea.
A movie that will get your heart thumping, and your adrenaline rushing.
I've never wanted to walk out of any movie more so in my life.

The story is solid, albeit a bit predictable at times, the songs, choreography, and costume design are all so stunning, and the cinematography and lighting are the best I've seen in years. Definitely give La La Land a visit.
If you're in the mood for something like Scarface but with some seriously hilarious moments that break up the drama and the tension, this is the perfect movie to find.
The Lobster just loses its charm at a certain point, and nothing interesting or exciting happens with the characters.
Either do something new and different with the Underworld franchise, or better yet, leave it dead.
If you saw the trailers and liked what you saw, go ahead and just buy one of the older video games in the series used for $4.99.
The movie is tight, well written, sympathetic, without resorting to cloying sentimentality, and brutal in its consequences.

The Founder is shot wonderfully; everything comes off as authentic to the time period the story is set in, and there's this dreamlike quality to the locations that gets juxtaposed with the asphalt and harsh lights of the franchised McDonalds locations.
Joe's Violin has a soundtrack that perfectly fits the story in tone and theme.
Two great leads can't overcome clunky dialogue and a story that overextends a healthy suspension of disbelief.
Every single actor involved in this picture, from the leads to the extras, is magnificent.
Despite its very minor flaws, this film was quite enjoyable, and I'll be strongly recommending it to just about everyone I know.
[Let's Play Two] does it so perfectly. It truly has to be experienced.
Future '38 is, hands down, the most original comedy I've seen in recent memory. Definitely catch this one as soon as you can.
Funny Story has an incredibly dry sense of humor that the actors execute perfectly. I was really sucked in by everything that was happening on screen.

Written and directed by Pavan Moondi, this is, unfortunately, an unfocused mess of a story, albeit one with two tremendous leads, beautiful cinematography, and some genuinely laugh out loud moments. And if you're a fan of Tim Heidecker, he kills it.
It's not a good movie, and I'd even go as far as saying that it's easily the worst of the Cloverfield flicks so far. Don't get caught up in the marketing hype, there are better things to watch.
Buster's Mal Heart is a magnificent film worthy of a Donnie Darko level cult following.
This isn't a Stranger Things/IT knock-off, it really does do its own thing and has its own tone...and then that tone goes to some ridiculously dark places.
My issues with the film are minor, it's certainly a good film that will entertain hardcore fans and those unfamiliar with Jett's music. Joan Jett truly is a remarkable human being.

It's never boring. It is constantly entertaining, inspirational, full of funny stories, and provides a look, if only somewhat superficial one, into the brilliant, lightning-fast mind and kind heart of the great Robin Williams.
movie_title: Robin Williams: Come Inside My Mind (2018)

movie_review_blurb: It will make you laugh, and it will certainly make you cry, but better yet it will make you appreciate Fred Rogers and his legacy, as well as hopefully inspiring you to be a little kinder towards the people you meet in life.
Dead Pigs is a weird, weird ride. Weird in a good way? Sure, sometimes. The film is unique.

The film does an exceptional job mixing its humor with melancholy. Serious moments are interrupted by laugh out loud jokes and gags, while levity and warm sentiment are crushed by failure and disappointment. At its core, this is a story about persistence.
More people should be talking about Brigsby Bear, it's such a well-made film with a great cast, a magnificent lead, and a premise that oozes with charm and originality.

The film features a talented cast and commendable special effects, and it looks amazing and competently shot, but the unfocused script and severe lack of personality in its characters makes the film nearly impossible for me to recommend.
The best horror films, in my opinion, forgo the cheap jump scares and aim to make you feel uneasy, vulnerable, and on guard. Creep 2 definitely has that quality in spades.

Happy Death Day cannot decide what kind of film it wants to be. It lacks the amount of comedy to be a proper horror comedy, and it lacks the scares and terror necessary to make it an effective horror film.
This is a movie that has to be seen, and it is an absolute recommendation for all those with a soft spot in their heart for bad, albeit entertaining films.
Patient 62 is a terrible movie, but still one that's worth a watch.
The Man From Earth: Holocene is a sequel that is quite enjoyable, but admittedly not as strong as the first classic film.
The humor is spot on, and the film drew some genuine laughs from me, especially the scene with Richie and the cricket bat.
Baby Driver is a frenetic, funky, fast and manic fun time at the movies you won't want to miss this summer.
It's beautiful scenic photography that has its powerful and important message overshadowed by lingering nature shots and a severe lack of focus.
The film's absurdly strong performances, music, and aesthetics all bring to life a wonderful film you won't want to miss. Do yourselves a favor, and buy a ticket when it comes your way.
There's a lot to enjoy with this one, so if you're in the mood for an indie twist on something fairly familiar, give Village People a watch.
It's unique, absurd, strange, and memorable.
Turn It Around: The Story of East Bay Punk is stimulating enough to appeal to non-punk rock fans as well. Definitely give it a watch.
movie_title: Turn It Around: The Story of East Bay Punk (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Generally, I enjoyed this film quite a bit. I don't have a lot of issues with this one aside from Addison Timlin's less than stellar acting and her character's useless part in the story.
Consistently naïve characters just do not appeal to me, but you cannot deny the sweet and tender qualities this film possesses, and I do think this film is engaging and an easy watch.
The Legend of Ben Hall doesn't offer much, especially those not well-versed on legendary Australian bushrangers. It's probably a good idea just to skip this one.
With an easily digestible runtime and an engaging performance by the very talented Oscar Isaac, Lightningface gets a high recommendation from me.
It has potential, but it just falls disappointingly short.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Even great acting cannot save an uninspired story with plot holes.

If Scott and screenwriter Seth W. Owen gave more attention to ideas than shocks and genre action, they might have come up with a fascinating picture. As it is, they've made their own Frankenstein's monster.

Before the series' creators decide they must give us a sixth installment, they'd do well to consider whether they're tired of the series regulars and should instead spin off the more interesting ones of recent vintage.
A moderately involving look at a man who helped shape the course of the NBA and those who aspire to play in the league on their own terms.
movie_title: Full Court: The Spencer Haywood Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's right that the respectful Queen Mimi lives up to its name doesn't condescend to its regal subject. Filmed over five years, it allows her to be a friendly guide through her life.
[The film] will only really find a very receptive audience among longtime fans.
movie_title: Now More Than Ever: The History of Chicago (2015)

movie_review_blurb: How this comes across will depend not just on your religious sympathies, but your tolerance for cloying dramatization.
That it's not terrible despite its debits is probably the most generous assessment of Jean-Claude Van Damme's latest, a watchable oddity.
Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children remains memorable not for what it does well, but for what it might have been.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: McLaughlin, for whom this is her first feature-length screenwriting credit, gives her characters incisive dialogue that keeps the human relations front and center. She also knows the value of silence and its ability to convey fear, dread and loneliness.

Even accepting that everything depicted about Doss' heroics are true, Hacksaw Ridge delivers them like someone too intent on wanting to make us feel good about ourselves for honoring the bravery and sacrifice of those soldiers.

Trim the excess running time from director Gore Verbinski's latest, and this old-school horror with a lesson would make quite the impression. However, at two-and-a-half hours, A Cure for Wellness is as needlessly overlong.

Nothing that follows Burn Country's jarring opening scene, which drops us without warning into an ongoing performance of an avant-garde play, quite lives up to its audacious intensity and strangeness.
The movie doesn't do anything new with this subject matter, but it hangs together for a little while because of a warm, sympathetic performance by Stefania Owen.
La La Land's exhilarating and nearly unflagging energy strives to inspire in viewers an equally bold appreciation for all the things it celebrates.

An affecting and enlightening documentary, The Bad Kids offers a fly-on-the-wall look at efforts to help students graduate high school despite their personal struggles and looming sense of hopelessness.
100 Streets doesn't fully develop one story; three threaten to float off the screen from weightlessness.
This cold, clinical approach might work intellectually, but instinctually it has us feel like unwilling voyeurs, forced to watch private moments.

While it succumbs to a lot of clichés that blunt its impact, Lavender shows that there are interesting ways to apply genre elements beyond the bump and chills, and in the service of story about memory, trauma, and resolution.
If your tastes run to the rude, crude and pleasantly bizarre-the laughs are there, doing the heavy lifting for a story that barely is.

There's a benefit to [the] light touch, as it keeps the movie from being consumed by self-seriousness, but by making McMahon the jokey center of the film, Michôd seems to let the D.C. establishment [off] the hook.
Viewed in the context of its intense combat scenes, The Dead Lands is a more-than-serviceable actioner distinguished by its exotic backdrop, gorgeous cinematography and engrossing performances.
Some 22 years after the Rwandan Genocide of 1994, The Uncondemned mixes firsthand accounts and courtroom footage to revisit a historical moment that would set a precedent in international law.

Though it doesn't carry the impact one would have hoped for, Growing Up and Other Lies finally intimates empathy for these modern musketeers clinging to the comfort of at least being there for each other.
